name: Etchmiadzin Cathedral
description: Etchmiadzin Cathedral is the spiritual center of the Armenian Apostolic Church, founded by Gregory the Illuminator at the beginning of the 4th century. It is one of the oldest Christian churches in the world and is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List.

name: Surb Zoravor Astvatsatsin
description: Surb Zoravor Astvatsatsin was founded in the 9th century, destroyed by the earthquake of 1679 and rebuilt in 1693–1694. It is one of the oldest surviving churches in Yerevan and a symbol of spiritual revival.

name: Geghard Monastery
description: Geghard Monastery, founded in the 4th century, is partly carved out of rock. It became famous for housing the spear that wounded Christ on the Cross. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Tatev Monastery
description: Tatev Monastery was founded in the 9th century and served as an important educational and spiritual center, housing one of the oldest universities of the Middle Ages in Armenia.

name: Khor Virap Monastery
description: Khor Virap is one of the most visited pilgrimage sites in Armenia. It is where Gregory the Illuminator was imprisoned for 13 years before converting King Tiridates III to Christianity in 301.

name: Noravank Monastery
description: Noravank, founded in the 12th century, is renowned for its dramatic setting in a narrow gorge and its unique two-story Surb Astvatsatsin church built by Momik the architect.

name: Sanahin Monastery
description: Sanahin Monastery, founded in the 10th century, was a major center of learning and culture. Today it is partially preserved and included in the UNESCO World Heritage List together with Haghpat.

name: Haghpat Monastery
description: Haghpat Monastery, dating back to the 10th century, is one of the most outstanding examples of medieval Armenian architecture. It was a major religious, cultural, and educational center.

name: Amberd Church (Surb Astvatsatsin)
description: The church of Surb Astvatsatsin at Amberd fortress was built in the 11th century by the Pahlavuni princes. It is partly in ruins but remains an important historical monument.

name: Zvartnots Cathedral
description: Zvartnots Cathedral, built in the 7th century under Catholicos Nerses III, was one of the most magnificent churches of early medieval Armenia. Destroyed by an earthquake in the 10th century, its ruins are a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Holy Transfiguration Cathedral (Moscow)
description: The Holy Transfiguration Cathedral, consecrated in 2013, is the main church of the Armenian Apostolic Church in Russia and the spiritual center of the community.

name: St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral (New York)
description: St. Vartan Cathedral is the main Armenian church in New York, consecrated in 1968. It serves as the center of the Armenian Apostolic Church in the USA.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church (Glendale)
description: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church in Glendale is one of the largest Armenian churches in California and the spiritual center of the local community.

name: Saint Catherine's Armenian Church
description: Saint Catherine's Armenian Church, designed by Yury Felten and built in 1771–1776, was consecrated on February 18, 1780, by Archbishop Joseph (Argutinsky) in the presence of Prince Potemkin. It is one of the oldest Armenian churches in Russia and has long served as a spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community.

name: Church of the Resurrection (Surb Harutyun)
description: The Church of the Resurrection (Surb Harutyun) in Rostov-on-Don, consecrated in 2011, was built in the traditional style of Armenian church architecture.

name: Holy Cross Church (Surb Khach)
description: Holy Cross Church (Surb Khach) in Nakhichevan-on-Don was built in 1786–1792. After being closed during the Soviet era, it was reopened in 2000.

name: Church of the Ascension
description: The Church of the Ascension in Chaltyr was founded in 1860. It has been functioning since 1944 and serves as the spiritual center of the Armenians in the region.

name: Saint Hripsime Church
description: Saint Hripsime Church is an Armenian Apostolic church in Astrakhan, serving as a functioning temple and the spiritual center of the local Armenian community.

name: Saint George Church (Surb Gevorg)
description: Saint George Church (Surb Gevorg) is an Armenian Apostolic church in Cherkessk, a functioning temple and spiritual center of the Armenian community in the city.

name: Saint Gevorg Church
description: Saint Gevorg Church in Volgograd is an active Armenian church, uniting the Armenian community of the city.

name: Saint Hovhannes Church (Surb Hovhannes)
description: Saint Hovhannes Church (Surb Hovhannes) is an Armenian Apostolic church in Maykop, serving as a spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community in the region.

name: Surb Karapet Church
description: Surb Karapet Church in Yekaterinburg is an active Armenian church, built at the end of the 20th century, bringing together the Armenian community of the Urals.

name: Church of Saint Sarkis
description: The Church of Saint Sarkis in Adler was built in 1997–1998. The temple is designed in traditional Armenian architectural style and serves as a spiritual center of the Armenian diaspora of the city.

name: Church of Saint Mariam Astvatsatsin
description: The Church of Saint Mariam Astvatsatsin is an Armenian Apostolic church in Krasnodar. It is an active temple serving as a spiritual and cultural center for Armenians of Kuban.

name: Church of Surb Vardan
description: The Church of Surb Vardan in Kislovodsk is an Armenian Apostolic church, an active temple founded in the early 21st century.

name: Church of Surb Sargis
description: The Church of Surb Sargis in Pyatigorsk is an active Armenian temple built with the support of the local community.

name: Church of Surb Gevorg
description: The Church of Surb Gevorg (Saint George) in Sultan-Saly was founded in 1795 and rebuilt in 1867. It is one of the oldest Armenian temples in the Don region. During World War II the building was damaged and partially destroyed. Today the church remains in ruins and requires restoration, but it is still regarded as an important monument of Armenian heritage in Russia.

name: Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator in Novorossiysk was built between 2001 and 2008. Designed by architect Levon Avalyan, the temple is clad in pink tuff brought from Armenia.

name: Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator in Vladimir is an Armenian Apostolic church consecrated in 2017. It was built with the support of the city’s Armenian community.

name: Church of the Holy Cross (Surb Khach)
description: The Church of the Holy Cross (Surb Khach) in Samara was built between 1998 and 2003 and consecrated in 2003. It serves as an active parish and the spiritual center of the Armenian community in the Volga region.

name: Church of St. Grigoris
description: The Church of St. Grigoris in Nyugdi was built in 1916. It remains an important religious center for the Armenian community of the region.

name: Church of Surb Sargis
description: The Church of Surb Sargis in Krasnoyarsk is the first Armenian church built east of the Urals. Constructed in the late 1990s, it was consecrated in 2003 and unites the Armenian community of Siberia.

name: Church of Surb Astvatsatsin
description: The Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Novosibirsk is an Armenian Apostolic church, serving as an active parish and cultural center for the local Armenian community.

name: Church of Christ the Savior
description: The Church of Christ the Savior in Kirov is an Armenian Apostolic church, serving as a spiritual hub for the Armenian community of the region.

name: Church of Surb Astvatsatsin
description: The Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Saratov is an Armenian Apostolic church, serving as an active parish and spiritual center for Armenians of the Volga region.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Ulyanovsk was consecrated in 2023. A modern Armenian Apostolic church built with the support of the local community.

name: Church of Surb Stepanos
description: The Church of Surb Stepanos in Kaliningrad is an Armenian Apostolic church and a spiritual center for the city’s Armenian community.

name: Church of Surb Harutyun
description: The Church of Surb Harutyun in Moscow was founded in 1815 by the Lazarev brothers. It was later closed, but returned to the community in 1956. Today it functions as an active parish and a historical cultural center.

name: Church of Surb Harutyun
description: The Church of Surb Harutyun in Tver is an active Armenian Apostolic church and a community center for Armenians of the city.

name: Church of Surb Gevorg
description: The Church of Surb Gevorg in Yaroslavl is the first Armenian church in the region, consecrated in 2017.

name: Church of Surb Sargis
description: The Church of Surb Sargis in Voronezh is an active parish of the Armenian Apostolic Church, built with Armenian tuff and decorated with khachkars. Architect: Gevorg Shirvanyan.

name: Church of Surb Amenaprkich (All-Savior)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Amenaprkich in Nizhny Novgorod was built between 2008–2014 and consecrated on May 25, 2014. Constructed from Armenian tuff, it features khachkars and a cultural center.

name: Church of Surb Ripsime
description: The Church of Surb Ripsime in Barnaul was built between 2001–2008, consecrated by Catholicos Karekin II in October 2008. Built in traditional Armenian style with red brick, with a khachkar nearby.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Sosnovka was registered in May 2008 and consecrated on August 24, 2008. The opening was attended by over 400 Armenians and representatives of other faith communities.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Vladikavkaz was built in 1868. It is a cultural heritage monument, with a khachkar in the yard dedicated to the memory of the Armenian Genocide victims.

name: Church of Surb Amenaprkich (All-Savior)
description: The Church of Surb Amenaprkich in Derbent was built in 1870–1871, with a bell tower added in 1888. Recognized as an architectural monument in 1975, services resumed in 2009.

name: Monastery of Surb Khach
description: The Monastery of Surb Khach (Holy Cross) was founded in 1358. The complex includes Surb Nshan Church, a gavit, refectory, cells, and khachkars. Closed in 1925, restored from the 1980s, services resumed in 1994.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: Built at the initiative of the Armenian community of Dnipro, the church was founded in 2003, with active construction beginning in 2010 using peach-colored tuff imported from Armenia. The consecration of the altar and domes took place in 2017, and the church was solemnly consecrated on March 17, 2018, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. The church hosts a Sunday school and is considered the largest Armenian church in Eastern Europe, serving as a major cultural and religious center.

name: Armenian Cathedral of the Assumption of the Holy Virgin
description: The Armenian Cathedral of the Assumption in Lviv is one of the city’s oldest landmarks. Built between 1363 and 1370 to the design of architect Doring, the church combines Armenian, Romanesque-Gothic, and Galician architectural elements and is included on the UNESCO World Heritage List. The complex includes the belfry (1571), archbishop’s palace, Armenian bank, Benedictine convent, St. Christopher’s column (1726), and southern arcade (1437). The interior features frescoes by Jan Henryk Rosen with Armenian motifs.

name: Holy Resurrection Church (Surb Harutyun)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Harutyun in Kharkiv was founded on July 1, 2000, and consecrated on August 24, 2004, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. The project was designed by Pavlo Chechelnytskyi, chief architect of Kharkiv. Built with stone imported from Armenia, the interior is decorated in traditional Armenian style.

name: Church of the Holy Apostles Peter and Paul
description: An Armenian Catholic church built for the Armenian community of Chernivtsi, designed by architect Josef Hlávka. Construction took place between 1869 and October 1875, and it was consecrated on October 9, 1875. The architecture blends Romanesque, Gothic, and Ukrainian Baroque styles. Known for its acoustics and organ, since 1986 it has served as the Organ Hall of the Chernivtsi Philharmonic. Closed during Soviet times, it was later restored and returned to the faithful.

name: Church of the Annunciation of the Holy Virgin
description: The Church of the Annunciation in Ivano-Frankivsk (historically Stanislaviv) was built by the Armenian community in the mid-17th century and became a spiritual center for the local Armenian diaspora. The building combines Baroque and Renaissance elements, with frescoes and icons dating to the 17th–18th centuries. The church was renovated in the 19th century, but suffered damage and losses during World War II and Soviet times. Religious life was restored in the 1990s, with cultural initiatives revived in the 2000s. Today, it remains a major spiritual and cultural center of Armenians in Galicia.

name: Armenian Apostolic Church of Odessa
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church in Odessa is located in the Gagarin Plateau district. It serves as the spiritual center of the Armenian community, hosting liturgies, baptisms, and weddings. The modern building, designed in Armenian architectural style, harmonizes with the Black Sea coastal landscape.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: The first Armenian church complex in Belarus — St. Gregory the Illuminator Church — was consecrated on May 18, 2025, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. Construction lasted from August 2022 to April 2025, designed by Armenian architect Samvel Makhyan. Built with volcanic tuff and travertine from Armenia, the church has become the spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community in Belarus.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator (Tallinn)
description:
The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Tallinn is an Armenian Apostolic Church. The building was originally a Lutheran church of St. John, dating back to the 13th century. The Armenian community received it in 1993 and restored it by the early 2000s. The consecration and installation of khachkars were performed with the participation of Armenian bishops.

Today it functions as an active church and the spiritual center of the Armenian community of Estonia, combining Armenian traditions with the historic fabric of Tallinn.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator (Riga)
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Riga is the first Armenian Apostolic church in the Baltic and Scandinavian countries. Its foundation stone was laid on December 17, 1997. Designed by Hakob Babakhanyan, it was clad in travertine imported from Iran. It was consecrated on June 30, 2011, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. The church also hosts a Sunday school named after Ghazaros Aghayan, and a khachkar made of Armenian tuff stands in the courtyard. Since 2005, the parish priest has been Fr. Khosrov Stepanyan (Ter-Khosrov). The church can hold around 100 worshippers.

name: Church of St. Vardan
description: The Church of St. Vardan in Vilnius was founded by the Armenian community of Lithuania. The parish was established in 1994, and the church was opened in 2006. It serves as the main spiritual and cultural center for Armenians in Lithuania.

name: Church of Surb Gevorg (St. George)
description:
The Church of Surb Gevorg in Vladivostok is one of the main spiritual centers of the Armenian community of Primorye. Armenians settled in the region at the end of the 19th century, and in 1906 the city council allocated land for a church and community house. By 1915, a prayer house was operating, and services continued until 1942, even under Soviet restrictions.

After WWII, the building fell into disrepair, and by the 1990s only ruins remained. Plans to demolish it were stopped by the Armenian community. In the early 2000s, a new church was built on the same site, with part of the old wall preserved as a monument.

The new church, built of red brick in traditional Armenian style, was consecrated in 2007. Today it is a cultural and spiritual symbol for Armenians in Vladivostok and the Russian Far East.

name: Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin)
description: The Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin) in Chisinau is one of the oldest Armenian churches in Bessarabia. Built in 1803–1804 on the site of a destroyed Moldovan church, its architecture includes an elongated nave, a two-tiered bell tower, and a three-arched portico. During Soviet times, it was used as a warehouse, but in 1992 it was returned to the Armenian community, and services resumed on June 19, 1993.

name: Church of Surb Karapet
description: The Church of Surb Karapet in Almaty is the first Armenian Apostolic parish in Kazakhstan. It was opened on October 7, 2006, with the support of the 'Nairi' Association of Armenian Cultural Centers. It was consecrated by Bishop Ezras Nersisyan. The parish hosts a Sunday school and cultural programs.

name: Church of St. Philip (Surb Pilipos)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Philip in Tashkent was founded by the Armenian community in 1993. After its closure during Soviet times, it was returned to the faithful following Uzbekistan's independence. The consecration and first liturgy were held in 1995. The church was officially registered on January 12, 2007, during the tenure of Fr. Gevorg Vardanyan. Today it is led by Fr. Garnik Loretsyan and serves as the center of the Armenian community in Tashkent.

name: Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin)
description: The Church of Surb Astvatsatsin (Holy Mother of God) in Samarkand was built in 1903 with funds from the local Armenian community, with Fr. Ruben Bekgulyants as its first pastor. It was closed in 1939 during the Soviet period. After Uzbekistan's independence, it was restored and re-consecrated in 1995 with the participation of Archbishop Nerses Pozapalyan. Today it serves as the cultural and spiritual center of Armenians in Samarkand.

name: Church of Surb Karapet
description:
The Church of Surb Karapet in Yakutsk is the northernmost Armenian church in the world. Its foundation was laid in 2011, and it was consecrated in 2012. The church is 27 meters high, with materials such as stone, glass, and wood brought from Armenia. The exterior is clad in natural tuff.

The Armenian community of Yakutia has existed since the late 19th century. Despite the harsh climate and remoteness of the region, Armenians preserved their faith and traditions. Today, the church unites Armenians of Yakutia and neighboring regions, serving as a major cultural and spiritual center.

name: Armenian Apostolic Church
description: A multifunctional Armenian spiritual and cultural complex in Izhevsk. It includes a church, a memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide, and a miniature of Mount Ararat with a pond shaped like Lake Sevan and fountains symbolizing the regions of Armenia. Built with support from the Armenian community of Udmurtia, it serves about 5,000 Armenians (around 3,000 in Izhevsk). The complex houses a national school and a library and is open to everyone. Today the church holds regular liturgies and religious rites and is the spiritual center of the region’s Armenian community.

name: Church of the Holy Resurrection
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Resurrection in old Armanitola, Dhaka, is one of the city’s oldest Christian structures. Built in 1781 on the site of a former wooden chapel at the cemetery, it was consecrated by Bishop Yeprem. The church preserves original Armenian architectural features with four arched doors, 27 windows, and wooden seating for about one hundred worshipers. Around it lies an Armenian cemetery with many granite tombstones. Today there is no permanent parish: services are held twice a year by an archbishop from Australia.

name: Church of St. Nazareth (Surb Nazareth)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Nazareth is one of Kolkata’s oldest Christian sanctuaries. Founded around 1708, rebuilt in 1724, and the current building dates to 1764. The interiors feature marble, frescoes, and paintings by A. E. Harris; the altar bears crosses, the Gospel, and candlesticks. The grounds include an Armenian cemetery with historic tombstones. Today the church remains a spiritual and cultural center for the city’s Armenian community.

name: Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin)
address: Chennai, Armenian Street, George Town, Tamil Nadu, India
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Mother of God in Chennai is one of the oldest on the Indian subcontinent. Built in 1712 and reconstructed in 1772, it is famed for its belfry with six bells, the largest weighing up to 150 kg, rung every Sunday at 9:30 a.m. Around the church lie about 350 Armenian graves, including that of Harutyun Shmavonyan, publisher of the first Armenian periodical, Azdarar. The church functions as a historical and cultural landmark and is open daily; services are held rarely.

name: Church of St. John
description: The Church of St. John in Chinsurah was built in 1697 (some sources say 1695) and dedicated to St. John the Baptist. It is the second-oldest Christian church in Bengal and the oldest Armenian church in India. Each year on January 13–14, a feast is celebrated in honor of St. John the Baptist, when relics are brought from the Armenian church in Nazareth (about 65 km away). Nearby is the family cemetery of the Melik-Beglaryan princes. The Armenian community began forming here in 1645, after the Dutch established the colony in 1625; by the late 19th century it was quite sizable. On March 1, 2007, Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II visited the church.

name: Church of St. John the Baptist
address: 66 Bo Aung Kyaw Street, Yangon, Myanmar
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. John the Baptist in Yangon is the country’s oldest and only active Armenian church. Built in 1862 and consecrated in 1863, it stands on land granted to the Armenian community by the King of Burma. The Armenian presence dates to the 17th century. Today only about 10–20 Armenian families remain; services are held regularly, often by a visiting priest.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in the Emirate of Sharjah is the principal spiritual center of the Armenian Apostolic Church in the UAE. Built in 1980 with the blessing of Catholicos Vazgen I and through the efforts of the Gulf Armenian community, it was consecrated by Archbishop Shaghe Aidemiryan. The complex, executed in traditional Armenian style with modern elements, includes the church, parish rooms, and a cultural hall. Today it serves Armenians across the UAE and neighboring countries.

name: Armenian Church in Payadzhuk
address: Payadzhuk village, Salmas County, West Azerbaijan, Iran
description: The church in Payadzhuk is almost completely ruined; only foundation traces remain. Cemeteries and the grave of Archimandrite Yeghiazar were also destroyed; khachkars were overturned and broken, and tombstones looted, especially after 2011. The village also housed the birthplace of the Armenian writer Raffi (Hakob Melik-Hakobyan, 1835), the remnants of which have likewise vanished.

name: Armenian Church of St. John in Sarna
address: Sarna village, Salmas County, West Azerbaijan, Iran
description: The Armenian Church of St. John in Sarna suffered extensive illicit excavations. Huge pits were dug inside the building and near the altar, damaging the walls. The destruction is linked to widespread treasure-hunting; both Christian and Muslim graves were disturbed.

name: Armenian Cemeteries in Salmas County
description: Armenian cemeteries at churches and separate clergy burials in Salmas County were destroyed: stones overturned, tombs dug up, khachkars disappeared. This wave of looting was especially intense after 2011.

name: Armenian Church in Turkmenbashi
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church was consecrated in 1905. In the early 1920s, Soviet authorities removed its dome and converted the building into an industrial facility. In recent years, Turkmen authorities have taken measures to protect the monument and have promised its full restoration.

name: St. Mary’s Church (Saidabad)
address: Saidabad, Cossimbazar, Murshidabad District, West Bengal, India
description:
The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Mary in Saidabad was built in 1757–1758 by merchant Khoja Petros Arathoon at his own expense in memory of his parents and brothers. Petros Arathoon was the head of the Armenian community of Calcutta. In 1827, Manasakan Vardan — a merchant and founder of the Armenian Philanthropic Academy — was buried here.

The church remained an important spiritual and cultural center for Armenians of West Bengal until its closure in 1860. In 2005–2006, the Armenian community of Calcutta carried out a major restoration, and in 2006 the church was reconsecrated.

Today St. Mary’s Church stands as a monument to the Armenian presence in India and as evidence of the active role Armenians played in the region’s history.

name: Armenian Chapel in Fort-Shevchenko
description:
The Armenian chapel in Fort-Shevchenko was built in 1893 by Armenian merchants from Astrakhan to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of victory over the Khiva Khanate. It is one of the few surviving Armenian religious buildings in Kazakhstan. The chapel features architectural traits reminiscent of traditional Armenian design, with an arched entrance and decorative columns.

After a long period of neglect, the chapel was restored and reconsecrated in October 2022. The consecration was performed by a priest from Astrakhan. Today the chapel serves as an important symbol of Armenian spiritual presence in Kazakhstan and as a reminder of the diaspora’s contribution to the region’s history.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church (Bălți)
description:
The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator is located in the historic center of Bălți. Construction took place from 1910 to 1914 with funding from the local Armenian community. The project architect was Alexander Leonidovich Krasnoselsky. The church, built of limestone and rubble stone, is styled after medieval Armenian ecclesiastical architecture, with harmonious proportions and a fitting integration into the landscape. Its height is about 16.8 meters.

The church is an important monument of Armenian culture and architecture in Moldova. Today the building is used as a Catholic church and no longer functions as an Armenian parish.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church (Singapore)
description:
The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator is the oldest Christian building in Singapore. It was built in 1834–1835 and consecrated in 1836. Designed by Irish architect George Drumgoole Coleman, it is in the neoclassical style, with a cruciform plan, Doric columns, and a distinctive spire. The church was the spiritual center of a small but influential Armenian community that made significant contributions to Singapore’s development.

The building was declared a national monument and has been protected by the state since 1973. Nearby is the 'Memorial Garden,' where Armenian tombstones from Fort Canning Hill and Bukit Timah have been relocated. Today the church continues to hold occasional services and remains a key symbol of Armenian heritage in Singapore.

name: St. Harutyun Church, Sydney
address: 10 Macquarie Street, Chatswood, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia
description:
The Church of St. Harutyun (Holy Resurrection) is an Armenian Apostolic Church and an active parish in Sydney. The building was purchased by the Armenian community in 1965 from a Baptist congregation. It was consecrated on February 27, 1966 by Bishop Komitas Der-Stepanian.

The church became a center of Armenian spiritual and cultural life: over time, it was renovated, expanded, fitted with a traditional Armenian dome and bell tower, an enlarged altar, marble altar table, and decorative friezes. Today, liturgies, educational and cultural events are held here, along with Sunday school, women’s and youth associations.

The church serves as an important spiritual stronghold for the Armenian diaspora of Australia and a symbol of their preservation of national and religious identity.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Buenos Aires
description:
The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Palermo, Buenos Aires, was built and consecrated in 1938 through the efforts of the Armenian community, with the participation of Bishop Karkegin Khachaturian on behalf of Catholicos Khoren I. The church serves as the cathedral of the Argentine Armenian Diocese and a center of the spiritual life of the Armenian Apostolic community in Argentina.

The building is included in official tourist routes of the city and recognized as an architectural and cultural heritage monument. Next to the church is 'Mount Ararat Square' with a symbolic fountain inaugurated in 1998, complementing its architectural and cultural setting.

The church continues to function actively, holding liturgies, cultural and community events, remaining an important spiritual center of the Armenian diaspora in South America.

name: Cathedral of Our Lady of Narek, Buenos Aires
address: Charcas Street, Palermo district, Buenos Aires, Argentina
description: The Armenian Catholic Cathedral of Our Lady of Narek (Nuestra Señora de Narek) is the main church of the Armenian Catholic Eparchy of San Gregorio de Narek in Buenos Aires. The land was purchased in 1942; the present building was constructed between 1971 and 1981 and consecrated in 1981. In 1983, 'Mount Ararat Square' was arranged in front of the church, and in 1998 a symbolic fountain dedicated to Ararat was installed. The cathedral follows the Armenian rite and is in full communion with Rome. Today, it is one of the key spiritual and cultural centers of the Armenian Catholic community of Argentina.

name: Armenian Chapel
description: The Armenian Chapel in Kunduz was built by Armenian peacekeepers with the support of international forces. Located near the airport, it was consecrated by Bishop Vrtanes Abrahamyan, spiritual leader of the Armenian Armed Forces, in July 2010. This chapel served as a spiritual place not only for Armenians but also for all Christians involved in the mission in the region.

name: St. Gevorg (Saint George) Church, São Paulo
description:
The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gevorg (Saint George) in São Paulo was founded in 1937, with the first church consecrated in 1938. After its demolition in 1943, Armenian philanthropist George Tahanian initiated the construction of a new temple, which began in 1945 and was consecrated in 1949.

The church is the spiritual center of the Armenian Apostolic community of Brazil, under the jurisdiction of the Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin. It serves as a place of worship and cultural events for the Armenian diaspora of São Paulo.

name: Holy Mother of God (Surb Mariam Astvatsatsin) Church, Toronto
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Mariam Astvatsatsin was founded in 1983 in North York as a parish under the jurisdiction of the Catholicosate of the Great House of Cilicia. Before acquiring its own building, services were held at St. Augustine’s Anglican Church. The new church was laid in 1987, consecrated on May 27, 1990, and underwent major restoration in 2012. The church actively serves the Armenian community of Toronto, holding liturgies, baptisms, weddings, as well as cultural and educational events.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Binghamton
address: 12 Corbett Avenue, Binghamton, New York, USA
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator is an Armenian Apostolic Church in Binghamton. Located at 12 Corbett Avenue, it is an active parish church. Divine Liturgy (Badarak) is held twice a month. It serves as a center of spiritual life and cultural events for the local Armenian community.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Houston
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator was opened in 1982 and serves the Armenian community of Houston and its surroundings. The parish is active, holding regular liturgies (Badarak). The church is served by Father Martiros Haobyan.

name: Holy Cross Church, New York
address: 580 West 187th Street, Washington Heights, Manhattan, New York, USA
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Cross (Surb Khach) is located in Washington Heights, Manhattan, New York. The building was erected in 1925–1926 by architect Stoyan N. Karastoyanoff for a Lutheran congregation, and since 1929 has been used by the Armenian Apostolic Church. It is an important spiritual center of the Armenian diaspora in New York, where Divine Liturgy (Badarak) is regularly held on Sundays and feast days.

name: St. James Church, Watertown
address: 465 Mount Auburn Street, Watertown, Massachusetts, USA
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. James (Soorp Hagop / St. James) is located in Watertown, Massachusetts — the center of the region’s Armenian community. The parish was founded in the 1930s, and the current church was built on Mount Auburn Street. It hosts regular worship services, educational and cultural events for parishioners.

name: St. Poghos Church, Syracuse
address: 310 N. Geddes St., Syracuse, New York, USA
description: St. Paul’s Armenian Apostolic Church in Syracuse is one of the oldest Armenian parishes in America, founded in 1908. Located at 310 N. Geddes St. since the purchase of the current building in 1956 and consecration in 1958, it has served as an active spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community in Syracuse. In 2010, the church was added to the U.S. National Register of Historic Places.

name: St. Sarkis Cathedral, Dearborn
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Sarkis was founded on May 24, 1942, on Waterman Street in Detroit. The current building in Dearborn was consecrated on October 14, 1962. The cathedral is under the jurisdiction of the Catholicosate of the Great House of Cilicia and serves as a spiritual center for Armenians of Eastern Michigan. The parish is active in community life, including support for the St. Sarkis Towers housing complex for elderly Armenians.

name: Church of Our Saviour, Worcester
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Our Saviour is the first Armenian church in the Western Hemisphere. Founded on January 18, 1891, the original building was constructed on Laurel Street by architect Stephen Earle. The current building, built in the Armenian cross-dome style, was consecrated in 1952 at the intersection of Salisbury and Dean Streets. The church serves as the spiritual center of the Armenian community of Worcester and belongs to the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America (Eastern).

name: St. Stepan Church, New Britain
address: 167 Tremont Street, New Britain, Connecticut, USA
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Stepan was founded in 1933. In 1953, land was purchased on Elton Avenue in New Britain, and construction of the new church began in 1956. It was consecrated by Archbishop (later Catholicos) Khoren I Paroyan on October 20, 1957. The church continues to serve as an active spiritual center of the Armenian diaspora of Connecticut.

name: Holy Trinity Armenian Apostolic Church, Fresno
description: The Armenian Apostolic Holy Trinity Church is one of the first Armenian churches in America. Laid on November 1, 1913, consecrated on December 13, 1914, its architect was Lawrence Karekin Cone. The church is an example of revived architecture with Armenian elements and the first Armenian church built in the traditional Armenian style in the USA. It seats up to 660 people. Listed in the National Register of Historic Places since 1986, the church remains an active spiritual center for the Armenian community of Fresno.

name: Armenian Evangelical Church, Montevideo
address: Luis Alberto de Herrera 3790, Montevideo, Uruguay
description: The Armenian Evangelical Church (Iglesia Evangélica Armenia) is the religious center of Uruguay’s Armenian Protestant community. Founded in 1926, it serves as the headquarters of this denomination in the country. The church is a member of the Federation of Evangelical Churches of Uruguay and connected with the World Council of Churches. A parish community functions here, along with a Sunday school and regular services.

name: Cathedral of Our Lady of Bzommar, Montevideo
description: The Armenian Catholic Cathedral of Our Lady of Bzommar (Catedral Católica Armenia Nuestra Señora de Bzommar) is the main church of Armenian Catholics in Montevideo and the cathedral of the Exarchate of Armenian Catholics of Latin America and Mexico. It is dedicated to the patroness of Armenian Catholics — the Holy Virgin Mary of Bzommar. The church is a key center of the spiritual life of the local Armenian community.

name: St. Nerses Shnorhali Cathedral, Montevideo
address: Av. Agraciada, Bella Vista, Montevideo, Uruguay
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Nerses Shnorhali is the cathedral of the Armenian Apostolic Church of Uruguay, dedicated to Catholicos Saint Nerses the Gracious. The modern building was constructed in 1968, designed by architect Rafael Israelyan. The church is integrated into a complex of Armenian institutions in the Bella Vista district and includes a memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide, created by sculptor Nerses Ounanian. The cathedral actively functions as a spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community of Uruguay, under the leadership of Archbishop Glnjyan.

name: St. George Church, Addis Ababa
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. George in Addis Ababa was founded on the site of a 1923 chapel, with the present stone building constructed in 1935 as a charitable project by Mikhran Muradyan in memory of his father Gevorg. The cornerstone was laid in 1928 with the participation of an archbishop from Constantinople, and Empress Menen Asfaw was present. The church belongs to the spiritual jurisdiction of the Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin and serves as the center of the Armenian community of Ethiopia. In its courtyard stands a khachkar memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide (installed in 2005).

name: Holy Resurrection Church, Mbabane
address: Pine Valley, outskirts of Mbabane, Eswatini
description:
The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Resurrection (Surb Harutyun) was founded in Pine Valley — a picturesque 'Valley of Pines' — by benefactor Grigor Derbelian in 1985. Construction lasted four years and was completed in 1989. The small chapel has two domes, one of which serves as a bell tower. Its foundation incorporates local materials, and the altar is organically built into the rock, reminiscent of the Geghard Monastery in Armenia.

Nearby runs a small river named 'Arax' by Derbelian in memory of his homeland. The church was consecrated according to strict Armenian canons and is an official parish of the Armenian Apostolic Church in the country. In January 2016, King Mswati III transferred the chapel to the jurisdiction of the Etchmiadzin Catholicosate. Despite its remoteness, the church is actively used by the local Armenian community for sacraments, including baptisms and weddings.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Khartoum
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator (Սուրբ Գրիգոր Լուսավորիչ) in Khartoum was founded in 1953 with funds from the Seferian family and consecrated in 1956. The decision to build was first made in 1933. The church served as the spiritual center of the Armenian diaspora of Sudan. During times of conflict, the church remained unharmed, and as of 2025, it still functions, though the community has shrunk to a few dozen people. Services are held under the jurisdiction of the Armenian Diocese of Egypt.

name: Surb Hripsime Church, Vienna
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Hripsime is the parish church of the Armenian community of Austria and the cathedral of the Diocese of Central Europe and Scandinavia. Laid in 1964; construction was based on the drawings of Armenian architect Eduard Sarabyan from Yerevan, executed by Walter Dürschmid. Consecrated on April 21, 1968, by Catholicos Vazgen I. The interior is decorated with traditional Armenian elements: a stone frieze with plant ornament, mosaics, and a memorial arch dedicated to the victims of the Genocide. Beyond its liturgical function, the church serves as a cultural and educational center (including the Hovhannes Shiraz school).

name: Holy Martyrs Church, Abu Dhabi
address: Bldg 16, Street M-26, Mussafah district, Abu Dhabi, UAE
description: The Armenian Apostolic 'Holy Martyrs' Church in Abu Dhabi is a parish under the jurisdiction of the Catholicosate of the Great House of Cilicia, serving the Armenian community of the UAE. Founded in 2014 in the Mussafah district. Built in Armenian style, the church functions as a spiritual, cultural, and educational center of the diaspora, with an active Sunday school. A khachkar stands in the courtyard as a memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide.

name: Mekhitarist Monastery, Vienna
description: The Armenian Catholic Mekhitarist Monastery (Armeno-Catholic branch) was opened in Vienna in 1811 as a branch of the order from the island of San Lazzaro (Venice). The modern building was erected according to the project of Joseph Kornhäusel: the foundation stone was laid in 1837, and the Church of Mary the Protectress was consecrated in 1874 (interior by Camillo Sitte). The monastery housed one of the largest collections of Armenian manuscripts (≈ 2,800), journals (≈ 70,000 volumes), coins (≈ 10,000 Armenian), and other cultural artifacts. Since 1889, it has also produced the herbal liqueur 'Mechitharine'. In 2015, a khachkar was erected in the courtyard in memory of the victims of the Armenian Genocide.

name: St. Mary Magdalene Church (Surb Mariam Magdalene), Brussels
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Mary Magdalene is the only Armenian church in Belgium, built with the support of the Armenian Church Foundation. It was designed by Armenian architect Haik Mardikian, with engineer Jacques Kupelian. Construction began after receiving permits in 1985, and it was consecrated on May 6, 1990, by Catholicos Vazgen I. The church is spiritually led by Father Zatik Avetisyan.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Armenian Apostolic Church, Cairo
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Cairo is a unique example of architectural synthesis, combining Armenian, Egyptian, French, and Coptic elements. Designed by a French architect using yellow tuff, its backdrop includes Islamic columns, Greco-Roman mosaics, and Armenian ornamentation. The entrance is adorned with motifs inspired by the Ibn Tulun Mosque; above it is a mosaic of Gregory the Illuminator. The interior includes Byzantine frescoes, Coptic motifs, icons, and wrought-iron details in the style of 18th-century France. The church remains the spiritual core of Cairo’s Armenian community, embodying valuable cultural dialogue.

name: Annunciation Cathedral, Cairo
address: Mohamed Sabry Abu Alam Street, Abdeen district, Cairo, Egypt
description: The Armenian Catholic Cathedral of the Annunciation (Annunciation Cathedral) in Cairo was built and inaugurated in 1926. It serves as the cathedral of the Armenian Catholic Eparchy of Alexandria (Eparchia Alexandrina Armenorum), founded in 1885 by Pope Leo XIII. The church is under the pastoral care of Bishop Kricor-Okosdinos Coussa. It is the spiritual center of Armenian Catholics in Egypt and Sudan.

name: St. Bartholomew Church
description:
St. Bartholomew’s Church in Genoa is an Armenian Catholic monastery of the 13th century, founded in 1308 by Armenian Mekhitarist monks. The church is dedicated to the Apostle Bartholomew, one of the Twelve Apostles of Christ and the first illuminator of Armenia, who, together with the Apostle Thaddeus, brought Christianity to the country.

The church preserves relics and a treasured fragment of the True Cross, donated in the 16th century. Its architecture combines Gothic and Romanesque elements, preserving its historical appearance to this day.

St. Bartholomew’s remains an active church, linking the Armenian community of Genoa with its spiritual and cultural heritage.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Livorno
description: The Armenian Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Livorno was built in the early 18th century (construction began in 1701, consecrated in 1714) by the city’s Armenian diaspora. It was designed by Giovanni del Fantasia, commissioned by Prince Ferdinando, son of Cosimo III. Destroyed during World War II, today only its elegant Baroque marble façade survives, featuring Andrea Vaccà’s sculptures 'Sacrifice' and 'Faith', along with an oval portrait of St. Gregory the Illuminator. Since 2008, the façade has been used as an intercultural center.

name: Holy Cross Church (Santa Croce degli Armeni), Venice
description: The Armenian Catholic Church 'Surb Khach' (Santa Croce degli Armeni) in Venice is the church of the Armenian community. Located on Armeni Street, near St. Mark’s Basilica. Its history goes back to 1434, when an altar and chapel were built here. In 1688, with merchant Murmanian’s permission, the chapel was expanded into a full church. In 1740, it was taken over by the Mekhitarist Order, which preserved it as a religious and cultural center. The church has a single nave with a dome, three altars adorned with Baroque paintings. Services are held once a month, on the last Sunday.

name: St. Nicholas of Tolentino Armenian Catholic Church, Rome
address: Salita di San Nicola da Tolentino, 17, Trevi district, Rome, Italy
description: St. Nicholas of Tolentino is one of two Armenian churches in Rome. Originally founded for the Order of Discalced Augustinians in 1599, it was rebuilt in the 17th century under architects led by Alessandro Algardi. Since 1883, it has been entrusted to Armenian Catholics along with a college. It houses the Pontifical Armenian College — the seminary of the Armenian Catholic Church. The church remains active to this day.

name: Mekhitarist Monastery (San Lazzaro degli Armeni)
description: The Mekhitarist Monastery on San Lazzaro Island in Venice is the main center of the Armenian Catholic order, founded in 1701 by Mkhitar Sebastatsi. In 1717, the community settled on the island, which soon became a spiritual and cultural hub of the Armenian diaspora. The monastery is renowned for its rich library (over 150,000 volumes and around 4,000 manuscripts), printing house (publishing books and journals since the 18th century), and as a place of education for clergy and scholars. Through the order’s activities, Armenian culture and language were preserved and represented in Europe. Today, the monastery remains an active center and pilgrimage site.

name: St. Blaise Church (San Biagio degli Armeni), Rome
address: Via Giulia, 64, Ponte district, Rome, Italy
description: The Armenian Catholic Church of St. Blaise, also known as San Biagio della Pagnotta or San Biagio degli Armeni, is located in Rome on Via Giulia. Founded before the 11th century, first documented in 1072; rebuilt in the 18th century (facade and interior). It is the national church of the Armenians, dedicated to the martyr St. Blaise (Blaise of Sebaste). Relics of his throat are kept here, as well as paintings by Pietro da Cortona, including the miracle of the fishbone and the Virgin of Mercy. Since 1856, the church has been under the jurisdiction of the Armenian Catholic community of Rome and is considered their national church.

name: Holy Mother of God Church (Surb Astvatsatsin), Shumen
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Mother of God (Սուրբ Աստվածածին) in Shumen was built in 1834 by a refugee Armenian community and consecrated with a dedicatory inscription. In 2001 the church was restored and a new bell tower was added. Marble slabs bearing the names of Armenian princes and benefactors of the 18th–19th centuries remain in the courtyard. In 1849 Lajos Kossuth and his followers celebrated Christmas here.

name: Holy Mother of God Church (Surb Astvatsatsin), Ruse
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Ruse is the oldest Armenian church in Bulgaria. The original wooden building was erected in 1610 but rebuilt in stone in 1832 after a fire. The church is listed as a cultural monument of Bulgaria. A khachkar memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide stands in the yard, and local Armenians revere it as a historic and spiritual center of the community.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: The Holy Mother of God Church in Silistra is an Armenian Apostolic church founded in the 19th century by the city's Armenian community. It served as a spiritual and cultural hub where liturgies, baptisms, and weddings took place. Despite historical trials and the community’s decline, the church has survived and continues to stand as a symbol of Armenian presence in the region.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: The Holy Mother of God Church in Sofia is an Armenian Apostolic church, opened in 2022 through the efforts of the Armenian community. Construction began in 2006 based on a design by Armenian architect Hagop Karakashian. The church combines traditional Armenian elements, such as sharp domes, with modern design and large windows. Today it functions as the cathedral and cultural-spiritual center of Armenians in Bulgaria.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: The Holy Mother of God Church is a 17th-century Armenian Apostolic church discovered during archaeological excavations in Veliko Tarnovo. Built on the site of an earlier Catholic structure, the wooden church burned down and eventually collapsed. Only fragments remain; it was once the only functioning Armenian church in Bulgaria, now abandoned and in ruins.

name: St. George Church (Surb Kevork), Plovdiv
address: 4-ti Januari St., Old Town, Plovdiv, Bulgaria
description: St. George Church (Surb Kevork) is an Armenian Apostolic church in Plovdiv. Originally an Eastern Orthodox church dedicated to St. George the Victorious, it was handed over to the Armenian community in 1767. Consecrated in 1828 after reconstruction. The church includes a crypt-museum preserving artifacts brought by Armenian refugees after the 1915 Genocide and serves as a religious, cultural, and historic center for the community.

name: St. Jacob Church
description: St. Jacob Church is an Armenian Apostolic church in Yambol, Bulgaria. It is the most modern church under the jurisdiction of the Armenian Apostolic Diocese of Bulgaria. Consecrated on September 24, 2017, by Archbishop Ezras Nersisyan with the support of patron Sonia Arshavir. Construction began in 2008, designed by architects Zhirayr and Alvard Patukanyan.

name: St. John Church
description: St. John Church is an Armenian Apostolic church in Dobrich, Bulgaria. Built in 1894 on the site of an older church from the 1830s, designed by Italian architects. A single-nave church with a stone foundation, stone walls, and a wooden roof. Inside, original images of Armenian saints painted in the late 19th century are preserved.

name: Holy Cross Church
description: Holy Cross Church is an Armenian Apostolic church in central Burgas, one of the city’s oldest structures. Built in 1853 on the site of a wooden chapel of St. Stepanos (1673). Consecrated in 1896 by Father Vahtang Sisakyan. A stone bell tower was erected in 1958 by engineer Grant Baklayan, featuring an inscription commemorating Catholicos Vazgen I. In 1970 the church gained the status of a Bulgarian cultural monument. A khachkar memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide, created by sculptor Hari Arabyian, was erected in 1991 in the courtyard.

name: St. Sarkis Church
description: St. Sarkis Church is an Armenian Apostolic church in central Varna, built in 1844 at the initiative of charismatic Father Hadji Sarkis. Located in the historic Armenian district, where a smaller memorial chapel once stood. The church follows traditional Armenian style with a single-nave basilica plan and characteristic bell tower. A khachkar memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide was erected in 2006 in the courtyard. The church is recognized as a Bulgarian cultural heritage monument and remains a spiritual center for Varna’s Armenian community.

name: St. Stephen Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Stephen in Pazardzhik was consecrated on December 18, 2011. Throughout history, Armenian churches had stood here since the 13th century, but all were destroyed by fires or earthquakes. The last, built in 1820, was demolished by disasters. The modern church was rebuilt after a fundraising campaign: foundation laid on July 4, 2005, consecrated in 2011 with a holy stone from Etchmiadzin placed in the altar. Today it is an active spiritual and cultural center, with the Armenian cultural club 'Arto Bozdigian' operating within it.

name: Holy Resurrection Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Resurrection in Halle (Saxony-Anhalt, Germany) was consecrated in 2007 with the participation of Catholicos Karekin II of All Armenians. Built with donations from the Armenian community of Germany, it became the first Armenian church in eastern Germany. Designed in traditional Armenian architectural style with a dome and khachkars brought from Armenia. It serves as the spiritual and cultural center for Armenians in Halle and the surrounding area, hosting liturgies, baptisms, and weddings.

name: Holy Trinity Church
address: 3/6 Mikołowska St., Gliwice, Silesian Voivodeship, Poland
description: The Armenian Catholic Holy Trinity Church in Gliwice is an architectural monument used by the Armenian Catholic community since 1945. Built between 1836 and 1838 on the site of a wooden church destroyed in 1813. Originally belonging to Old Catholics, it was transferred to the Armenian Catholic community after World War II. It remains an active parish church to this day.

name: St. Peter and Paul Church
description: The Church of Saints Peter and Paul in Gdańsk is an outstanding example of brick Gothic, built between 1396 and 1516. In 1958, the church was granted for use by Roman and Armenian Catholics, and today it serves as the parish church of the Armenian Catholic community. In 2009, a khachkar memorial was erected in the Armenian Alley courtyard, where liturgies are conducted in Armenian.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin) in Athens was built in 1935 on the site of a wooden church that had existed since 1908 and became the spiritual center of the Armenian community. It also serves as the residence of the Armenian Prelacy of Greece and fosters cultural and religious ties between the diaspora and the homeland.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Mother of God in Thessaloniki has been a religious and cultural center of the Armenian community for over 120 years. Built by Italian architect Vitaliano Poselli, consecrated on November 6, 1903. Its architecture blends Armenian and local traditions: the facade crowned by a central tower, side towers resembling Armenian domes. The interior features frescoes and stained glass depicting the life of the Virgin Mary. The church also plays social roles, including education and charity. Nearby stands a khachkar memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Komotini was built with funds from the Armenian community and consecrated on November 25, 1834. Built in classic Armenian style, it stands in the city center and serves as the main spiritual and cultural hub of the local Armenian diaspora.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
address: 2 Rene Pio St., Neos Kosmos, Athens, Greece
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator is the cathedral of the Armenian Apostolic Prelacy of Greece. Located in Neos Kosmos, Athens, built in 1935 on the site of a wooden church (1908), it was consecrated as the spiritual center of the diaspora. It serves as the Prelate’s residence and organizes the religious, cultural, and educational life of Athens’ Armenian community.

name: St. John the Baptist Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. John the Baptist is one of the oldest Armenian churches in Europe. Transferred to the Armenian community in 1669 after the Ottoman conquest of Heraklion. It remains the spiritual center of the Armenian diaspora of Crete and is still active today.

name: St. Karapet Church
address: 4 Praksagoru St., Neos Kosmos, Athens, Greece
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Karapet (Surb Karapet), also called St. John the Baptist, is located in Neos Kosmos, Athens. It serves as a center of Armenian spiritual life in the city under the jurisdiction of the Armenian Apostolic Church.

name: Armenian Catholic Church of the Holy Mother of God
description: The Armenian Catholic Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin) is the spiritual center of the Armenian Catholic community in Hungary, located in Budapest’s 11th district. Close to the famous Gellért Baths, the church is an architecturally and culturally significant monument for Hungary’s Armenians.

name: St. Sarkis Church
address: Iverna Gardens, Kensington, London W8 6TP, United Kingdom
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Sarkis in Kensington is the cathedral of the Armenian Apostolic Diocese of the UK. Built in 1922–1923 by architects Arthur Davis and Charles Mewes, funded by Calouste Gulbenkian in memory of his parents. The only Armenian church in England constructed in traditional Armenian style, inspired by the bell tower of Haghpat Monastery. Consecrated on January 11, 1923; expanded in 1937–1950; listed as a Grade II* monument in 1981.

name: St. Yeghishe Church
address: Cranley Gardens, South Kensington, London SW7, United Kingdom
description: St. Yeghishe Church is the largest Armenian Apostolic church in the UK. Built in 1867 as an Anglican church dedicated to St. Peter, commissioned by developer Charles Freake. Declared redundant in 1972, it was acquired in 1998 by a benefactor, restored for Armenian liturgy, and became an Armenian church. It features a four-manual organ, constructed of ragstone in the Victorian 'Decorated' Gothic style, with a broach spire and refined interior.

name: Holy Trinity Church
address: Upper Brook Street, Chorlton-on-Medlock, Manchester, United Kingdom
description: The Armenian Apostolic Holy Trinity Church in Manchester is the first Armenian church built in Western Europe, consecrated on Easter 1870. Constructed in 1869–1870 by Liverpool architects Royle and Bennett in eclectic Neo-Gothic style. It is listed as a Grade II building for its historic and cultural significance.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Almelo was consecrated in November 2003. Built with funds from the local Armenian community after selling their previous parish building, transformed from a multi-purpose hall with Sunday school rooms (founded in 1991). The church hosts a youth union, women’s union, Sunday school named after Mesrop Mashtots, a diaconate, and the 'Zartonk' ensemble. A memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide was installed on the grounds in April 2014.

name: St. Karapet Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Karapet in Maastricht was consecrated on January 26, 2013. It is the third Armenian church in the Netherlands (after Amsterdam and Almelo). The building is a reconstructed Catholic property handed over to the Armenian community. The parish hosts a Sunday school, women’s union, youth and cultural associations under the name 'Ani'.

name: Holy Spirit Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Spirit (*Surb Hoki*) is the first Armenian church in Amsterdam, founded around 1714. Built through the efforts of Armenian merchants on purchased land; renovated in 1747–1749 by priest Johannes Minas Amasiatsi and his successor. In 1985 the church was purchased and restored by the Armenian diaspora, and reconsecrated on November 29, 1989. A khachkar was erected in the courtyard as a memorial, and in 2018 another cross-stone was added in memory of the war victims of Artsakh, supported by the community.

name: St. Hakob Church
address: Route de Troinex 64, 1256 Troinex, Geneva, Switzerland
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Hakob is the only Armenian Apostolic church in Switzerland. Built between 1967 and 1969 with donations from Hakob Topalian. The consecration took place on September 14, 1969. It serves the Armenian community of Geneva and remains its spiritual center.

name: Armenian Apostolic Church of the Forty Martyrs
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Forty Martyrs of Sebaste (Chiesa dei Quaranta Martiri di Sebaste) in Milan is the only Armenian Apostolic church in Italy. Built in 1957 to the designs of architects R. Israelyan and P. Suryan, consecrated in 1958. The interior is decorated with old murals, creating an atmosphere of spiritual and aesthetic harmony. The church has become the center of religious, cultural, and communal life for Armenians in Lombardy.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
address: Boulevard du Bourg-d’Issy, Issy-les-Moulineaux, Paris Suburb, France
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Astvatsatsin (Holy Mother of God) in Issy-les-Moulineaux, a suburb of Paris, belongs to the Armenian Apostolic Church of France under the jurisdiction of the Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin. Built by architect Henri Kanjyan and consecrated in 1975. Its altar was renewed in the early 2000s under Tigran-Manvel Deirmendjian and reconsecrated on April 7, 2001 by Archbishop Kude Nakatian.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
address: Boulevard de la Madeleine, Nice, France
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Astvatsatsin (Holy Mother of God) in Nice belongs to the French Diocese of the Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin. The church serves as the spiritual center of the Armenian community of Nice, hosting liturgies and preserving national traditions.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
address: Komitas Street, Chaville, Hauts-de-Seine Department, France
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Grigor Lusavorich in Chaville belongs to the French Diocese of the Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin. It serves as the spiritual center for the Armenian community of Chaville and surrounding areas.

name: Holy Translators Church
address: 339 Avenue du Prado, 8th District, Marseille, France
description: The Catholicosal Cathedral of the Armenian Apostolic Church in Marseille, consecrated on October 25, 1931, designed by architect Aram Tahtadjian with reference to the Etchmiadzin Cathedral. Dedicated to Saints Sahak Parthian and Mesrop Mashtots. In the garden stand monuments: the bust of Vahan Khorasanyan, the bust of Grigor Balakian, and a Genocide memorial unveiled in 1973.

name: Holy Cross Varag Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Khach–Varag (Holy Cross of Varag) in Arnouville-lès-Gonesse was built in 1931 on land donated by benefactor Armenak Ambartsumyan. Architect: Armen Aopyan. The cornerstone was laid on August 2, 1931, by Bishop Vramshapuh Kibaryan. The church’s tower is crowned with an octagonal dome in Armenian style. In the yard stands a khachkar memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide.

name: St. Hakob Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Hakob (St. James) in Lyon is an active parish under the jurisdiction of the Armenian Diocese of France. Founded in 1963 and dedicated to the Apostle James, one of the Twelve Apostles. Located on Rue d’Arménie, it serves as the spiritual center of Lyon’s Armenian community.

name: Armenian Cathedral of St. John the Baptist
description: The Armenian Apostolic Cathedral of St. John the Baptist in Paris was built by architect Albert Guilbert at the initiative of oil magnate Alexandre Mantashev. Construction began on October 5, 1902 and was completed in 1904. The cathedral became the spiritual center of the Armenian community of France and a symbol of its cultural solidarity.

name: Holy Cross Cathedral
address: 13–15 Rue du Perche, 3rd District, Paris, France
description: The Armenian Catholic Cathedral of the Holy Cross in the Marais, Paris. Originally the church of Saint-Jean-Saint-François, built in 1623. Transformed into the Armenian cathedral in 1970 and, since 1986, has served as the seat of the Sainte-Croix-de-Paris Armenian Eparchy. The church preserves its historic architecture, Victor Baltard’s portico, and antique organs.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Iași is one of the oldest churches in the city, built in the 14th century and dedicated to the Dormition of the Mother of God. The church was restored in 1803 and again after World War II. Inside, a stone inscription dated 1395 has been preserved, though its origin remains debated. The building is recognized as a historical monument of Romania.

name: St. John the Baptist Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Hovhannes Mkrtich (St. John the Baptist) in Pitești was built in 1852 in a trefoil shape with a hexagonal spire. It is an architectural monument and serves as the spiritual center of the Armenian community of the city.

name: Holy Archangels Church
address: 43 Carol I Boulevard, Sector 2, Bucharest, Romania
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Archangels Michael and Gabriel is the cathedral of the Armenian Church in Romania. The cornerstone was laid in July 1911. Built to the designs of Armenian architects Dimitrie Maimarolu and Grigore Cerchez in the style of Etchmiadzin Cathedral, it was consecrated in September 1915. The complex includes the bishop’s residence, library, museum, cultural center, kindergarten, and the headquarters of the Union of Armenians of Romania. It is listed as a national historic monument.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Astvatsatsin, also known as 'Meskinta', was founded in 1639–1640 by an Armenian officer serving under Sultan Murad IV. The church was restored multiple times, particularly in the 19th century, and underwent major reconstruction between 1967 and 1970 under Catholicos Vazgen I and Archbishop Asoghik Ghazarian, supported by benefactors. During this renovation, the crypt containing the relics of the '40 Martyrs of Sebaste' was rediscovered.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
address: Old Basra District (Al-Basra al-Qadima), Basra, Iraq
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Astvatsatsin is the main spiritual and cultural center of Armenians in Basra and its surroundings. First built in 1736 on the site of an older church and repeatedly restored. Inside is a portrait of the Virgin Mary brought from India in 1882.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral
address: Al-Tayaran Square, Bab al-Sharqi District, Baghdad, Iraq
description: The Armenian Apostolic Cathedral of Surb Grigor Lusavorich (St. Gregory the Illuminator) is the seat of the Armenian Apostolic Diocese of Iraq. Built between 1954 and 1957 on land that included an Armenian cemetery established in 1904. Funded through a major donation by Calouste Gulbenkian. Its features include a white reinforced concrete façade, an octagonal dome with ornamentation, and a metal cross on top. In front stand two Genocide memorials (1990 and 2015), while the interior contains realistic murals depicting scenes of the Armenian Genocide.

name: St. James Cathedral
description: The Armenian Cathedral of St. James is the main church of the Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem, built in the 12th century incorporating parts of two ancient chapels from the 5th century. Dedicated to St. James the Greater and St. James the Just (brother of the Lord), whose relics are preserved here. The cathedral is the spiritual and administrative center of the Armenian community of the Old City and the patriarchal seat.

name: St. Nicholas Armenian Monastery
description: The Armenian Monastery of St. Nicholas in Old Jaffa is one of the oldest monasteries of the Armenian Apostolic Church, founded before the 10th century near the port of Jaffa. It served as a hostel for pilgrims and sailors. Expanded and fortified in the 18th century. Napoleon visited this monastery during his campaign, meeting plague-stricken soldiers and thanking the Armenian priests. Today the complex includes the church and residential quarters and is under the jurisdiction of the Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem.

name: Armenian Shrines in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre
description: The Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem, one of the holiest sites in Christianity, has long included the historical and spiritual presence of the Armenian Apostolic Church. The Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem is one of the three main communities sharing service and governance of the church. Among the Armenian-held sanctuaries is the Chapel of St. Helena, built where Empress Helena is said to have discovered the True Cross. Nearby stands the Chapel of St. Vardan Mamikonian and Companions, commemorating 5th-century Armenian martyrs. In the Edicule above the Holy Tomb burns an Armenian Church lamp, symbolizing continuous Armenian participation. The Patriarchate shares responsibility for liturgy, maintenance, and custodianship of the site.

name: Tomb of the Virgin Mary (Church of the Dormition)
description: The Tomb of the Virgin Mary is an underground shrine of the 17th century (preserving 5th-century elements) in Gethsemane, on the western slope of the Mount of Olives, where according to tradition the apostles buried the Holy Virgin Mary, and on the third day found the tomb empty. The cave church was built during the Crusades in the 12th century. The sanctuary contains three altars: the Armenian chapel of St. Joseph the Betrothed at the west of the Edicule; the others belong to the Greek Orthodox and Syriac-Coptic communities. Pilgrims descend a 48-step stone staircase to the marble Edicule surrounding the tomb, about 2×2 meters, and to the Chapel of Saints Joachim and Anne.

name: Armenian Altar in the Church of the Nativity
address: Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem, Palestine
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church maintains its own altar in the Church of the Nativity, built above the grotto where Christ was born according to tradition. The governance, liturgical rights, and upkeep of the church are shared by the Greek Orthodox, Armenian, and Roman Catholic communities under the 'Status Quo'. The Armenian community holds the northern transept and its altar, while sharing custody of the Nativity grotto’s altar with the Greeks. On the silver star marking the birth site, five of the lamps belong to the Armenians, six to the Greeks, and four to the Catholics. Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 18–19, using their altar for liturgy. The Armenian altar is not only an architectural element but a living testimony of centuries of presence and service of the Armenian Church in Bethlehem.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Bourj Hammoud
description: The Holy Mother of God Church (Surb Astvatsatsin) in the Nor-Adana district of Bourj Hammoud was built by Armenian refugees after the Genocide and became the spiritual heart of the district. It plays a key role in community life: liturgies, baptisms, weddings, and Sunday school are held here. Inside are icons and relics brought from Western Armenia. The church also functions as a cultural and charitable center, uniting Lebanese Armenians in faith and identity.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral, Antelias
description: The Cathedral of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Antelias is the seat of the Catholicosate of the Great House of Cilicia. Built in the mid-20th century, it became a symbol of Armenian presence in Lebanon. The cathedral features monumental architecture in the style of medieval Armenia. It hosts ordinations, church synods, and ecumenical meetings. The cathedral is surrounded by a large complex: the Catholicos’s residence, a seminary, museum, and library. It is not only a religious but also a cultural hub for Armenians across the Middle East.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Zahlé
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Zahlé was built by the city’s Armenian community, formed by survivors who resettled from the Ottoman Empire. It serves as a spiritual and cultural center for Armenians of the Beqaa. Liturgies, baptisms, weddings, and community celebrations take place here. The church actively engages in the city’s social life, fostering intercommunal ties and preserving Armenian identity.

name: St. Gevorg Church, Beirut
description: St. Gevorg Church (Surb Gevorg) is located in the center of Beirut and is one of the capital’s main Armenian churches. Built in the 20th century, it became a spiritual refuge for thousands of Armenians who settled in Lebanon. The church is built in the traditional Armenian style and remains an active parish, hosting liturgies, celebrations, educational, and cultural activities. St. Gevorg is a vital part of the religious and cultural life of Lebanon’s Armenian diaspora.

name: St. Hakob Church, Beirut
description: The St. Hakob Church (Surb Hakob) in Beirut is one of the important churches of the Armenian community. Built in the 20th century by the diaspora, it was named after the Apostle James. Regular liturgies, celebrations, and commemorations are held here. The church plays a key role in preserving the spiritual and cultural identity of Armenians living in Lebanon’s capital.

name: Holy Resurrection Church, Jounieh
description: The Church of the Holy Resurrection (Surb Harutyun) in Jounieh, a city known as a center of the Armenian diaspora, was built in the second half of the 20th century. The church’s austere and modern architecture reflects its era. It actively serves the Armenian community of Jounieh, hosting liturgies, baptisms, weddings, and cultural celebrations. The church has become a symbol of Armenian spiritual renewal in Lebanon.

name: Holy Pentecost Church, Tripoli
description: The Holy Pentecost Church (Surb Hogegalust) in Tripoli is an important spiritual center for Armenians of northern Lebanon. Built by the Armenian community after resettlement, it serves as a place of worship, education, and charity. The church is especially noted for its Pentecost liturgies, drawing Armenians from across the region.

name: St. Nshan Church, Beirut
description: The St. Nshan Church (Holy Sign) in Beirut is one of the city’s oldest Armenian churches. Built in the 20th century, it symbolizes the spiritual revival of the Armenian community. Liturgies, weddings, baptisms, and cultural programs are held here. The church unites Beirut’s Armenians, serving as a symbol of their faith and national unity.

name: St. Paul Church, Anjar
description: The St. Paul Church (Surb Poghos) in Anjar is the main church of the unique Armenian community of the town, founded by refugees from Musa Dagh (Syria) in 1939. The church became the spiritual center of the community, hosting liturgies, celebrations, and commemorations. It symbolizes the preservation of Armenian faith and traditions in exile and strengthens the national identity of Anjar’s residents.

name: St. Thaddeus Church
description: The St. Thaddeus Church in Amman is an Armenian Apostolic church serving as the spiritual and cultural center of Jordan’s Armenian community. Dedicated to Apostle Thaddeus, one of the first preachers of Christianity in Armenia. Regular liturgies, celebrations, and rites are held here, along with Sunday school and cultural initiatives. The church plays a vital role in preserving the spiritual life and national identity of Armenians living in Amman and nearby regions.

name: St. Mark’s Church
description: St. Mark’s Church in Qamishli is the spiritual center of the Armenian community of northeastern Syria. Built in the 20th century, it became a place of prayer and cultural life for Armenians who resettled after the 1915 Genocide. The church functions under the jurisdiction of the Armenian Apostolic Church.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Qamishli
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Qamishli is one of the main churches of Armenians in northeastern Syria. Built in the early 20th century by Armenian refugees who survived the Genocide, it became a center of spiritual and educational life, with schools and cultural circles founded here. Today it remains a symbol of the resilience of Qamishli’s Armenians despite years of war in the region.

name: St. Karapet Church, Qamishli
description: The Church of St. Karapet in Qamishli was founded by settlers from Western Armenia in the 1920s. Dedicated to John the Baptist (Surb Karapet), it serves as a spiritual refuge for the local Armenian community. The church also hosts a parish school and cultural circles that play an important role in preserving language and traditions. Despite instability in Syria, the church remains a place of strength and faith.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral
description: The Cathedral of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Aleppo is the city’s main Armenian cathedral, built in the 1930s in memory of the victims of the Armenian Genocide. It is the regional center of the Armenian Apostolic Church, surrounded by schools and cultural institutions.

name: Surb Karapet Church, Aleppo
description: The Surb Karapet Church in Aleppo was founded in the early 20th century in the Armenian resettlement quarter. One of the city’s oldest Armenian parishes, it is known for its active parish and educational life.

name: St. Hripsime Church, Damascus
description: The Church of St. Hripsime in Damascus is one of the oldest Armenian churches in the Syrian capital. Dedicated to the martyr Hripsime who brought Christianity to Armenia, it served as a spiritual center for Armenians relocated to Damascus in the Ottoman era, and later became a refuge for refugees from Anatolia after the Armenian Genocide. Today, it is active with liturgies, feasts, and a parish Sunday school.

name: St. Sarkis Church, Damascus
description: The Church of St. Sarkis in Damascus was built by the Armenian community in the 19th century and became a center of spiritual and cultural life. Dedicated to St. Sarkis the Warrior, one of Armenia’s beloved patron saints, the church is also known for its parish school and council activities. It continues to preserve Armenian tradition and communal unity.

name: Surb Astvatsatsin Church, Idlib
