description: The Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Idlib served as a place of worship for the Armenian community until the outbreak of war in Syria. Today it stands as a reminder of the once-numerous Armenians of the region.

name: Surb Sarkis Church, Idlib
description: The Church of Surb Sarkis was built by the Armenian community of Idlib and served for worship until the outbreak of the civil war. Today it is heavily damaged and no longer functions.

name: Bzommar Monastery, Homs
description: The Armenian Catholic Monastery of Bzommar in Homs was founded in the 19th century and served as the center of the Armenian Catholic community of the region. It housed schools and cultural institutions connected with the church.

name: Surb Harutyun Church, Kessab
description: The Surb Harutyun Church in Kessab is one of the main churches of the Armenian community of northern Latakia. Built by settlers from Cilicia, it plays a vital role in the cultural and spiritual life of the region.

name: St. Karapet Monastery
description: The Monastery of St. Karapet, founded in the Middle Ages, was one of the spiritual centers of Armenian monasticism in Syria. Today it lies in ruins but retains historical significance.

name: St. Hripsime Church
description: The 7th-century martyrion built over the tomb of St. Hripsime is an exemplar of solemn and inspired Armenian architecture. Here we learn steadfastness of faith and purity of heart; prayer before the saint’s relics strengthens us in courage and love which ‘never fails’.

name: St. Gayane Church
description: St. Gayane, with her companions, sealed the Gospel with her blood. This beautiful 7th-century church stands over her tomb, where prayers for peace, families, and teachers of faith rise warmly. The soul finds a haven here, and the church’s beauty nurtures meekness of heart.

name: Shoghakat Church
description: “Shoghakat” means “ray of light” — a memory of the grace that shone on the site of the martyrs’ death. This church is a prayer school of thanksgiving to God for the light of Baptism and the path of sanctification followed by the Armenian Church through the ages.

name: Sevanavank
description: The monastery on the island-lighthouse: here water and sky become icons of Baptism and Resurrection. Sevanavank calls to renewal of life and watchfulness of heart — like morning prayer over the lake.

name: Saghmosavank
description: The 'Monastery of Psalms' on the edge of a picturesque canyon. For centuries, the Church here taught the people to sing the Psalms so that the Word of God would dwell with wisdom and thanksgiving. A place where the echo of Armenia’s prayers resounds.

name: Hovhannavank
description: Strong as the rock, this monastery guarded the faith of border villages. Its strict forms instruct in courage and unity; here the liturgy sustains daily labor and nurtures brotherly love.

name: Akhtala Monastery
description: Akhtala is famed for its magnificent frescoes — theology in colors. In them, intellectual faith and prayerful heart unite for the edification of the faithful. The monastery teaches us to contemplate Beauty and live it out in deeds of mercy.

name: Odzun Monastery (Holy Mother of God Church)
description: Odzun Monastery, lying on a plateau above the Debed canyon, is an ancient domed basilica of the 6th century, renewed in the 19th and 21st centuries. Its pink felsite walls echo prayers and psalms, while the double-storied sacristies and choirs continue the angelic song. Here, ancestral memory and the power of faith remain in stone, revived by each trembling heart.

name: Vahanavank Monastery
address: ≈ 5 km west of Kapan, Syunik Province, Armenia
description: Vahanavank is a 10th-century monastery founded in 911 by Prince Vahan, son of Syunik’s ruler Dzaqik. It includes the Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator, to which were later added a gavit, columned hall, and two-storied Church of the Holy Mother of God. The complex served as the royal necropolis of the Syunik dynasty and as the region’s spiritual center. Nearby are khachkars, ruins, a medieval school, and a 10th-century spring. Today it remains a spiritual beacon of Syunik.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral
address: Yervand Kochar St., Kentron District, Yerevan, Armenia
description: This majestic cathedral was a gift of the nation for the 1700th anniversary of Christianity as Armenia’s state religion. Its jewel-carved stone proclaims the faith, and at its heart are relics of St. Gregory the Illuminator brought from Naples. The cathedral is not just a building but the Mother Church’s home, where the liturgy flows like a river of grace and prayer rekindles hearts with fire.

name: Holy Resurrection Church (Surb Harutyun)
description: In 2024, the Church of the Holy Resurrection (Surb Harutyun) was consecrated in Nakhodka as the spiritual home of Primorye’s Armenian community. Built with local diaspora efforts and support of the diocese, constructed from tuff imported from Armenia, it became a symbol of faith and unity. Its walls recall the homeland, while prayers within link the Far East to Armenia’s spiritual heart. Today it serves as a center for worship, feasts, and gatherings, strengthening generational ties.

name: Holy Mother of God Church
description: In 2022, the Holy Mother of God Church was built in Malaga, becoming the first Armenian church on Spanish soil. Just as a mother carries and protects, this house of prayer became a haven for Armenians arriving from afar. Built from light tuff brought from the homeland, it serves as a hearth of faith, uniting hearts through word and song even far from native mountains.

name: Karmravor Church (Surb Astvatsatsin)
description: Karmravor is a small yet precious 7th-century church crowning the slopes of Ashtarak. Its modest walls convey an Old Testament truth: faith is not measured by size. Bathed in the stillness of sunset, the church reminds us that God reveals Himself not in scale but in a heart open to humility and prayer.

name: St. John the Baptist Church (Mastara)
address: Mastara village, Talin District, Aragatsotn Province, Armenia
description: Surb Hovhannes in Mastara is one of the oldest sanctuaries of the 5th century, where architectural grandeur merges with humility of faith. From its dome, the soul soars heavenward, while surrounding khachkars seem to sing psalms in stone. Here we surrender to holiness and recall that truth dwells in man-made prayer and in the legacy of St. John.

name: St. Mesrop Mashtots Church
description: On the sacred ground of Oshakan stands the Church of St. Mesrop Mashtots, the father of Armenian letters. Beneath its altar rests the saint who gave the nation the alphabet with which we glorify Christ today. Built in the 12th century on the site of an ancient crypt (443 AD) and restored in the 19th century, it preserves the memory of the creator of the alphabet and the power of enlightenment. Frescoes, bell tower, chapel, and school all radiate faith and thanksgiving.

name: Kecharis Monastery
description: Kecharis is an ancient monastic stronghold in the valley of flowers, where the power of faith meets the beauty of creation. Founded in the 11th century by the Pahlavuni princes, the complex stands on the slope of the Pambak Range, amid birches and mountain wind. In its four churches, two chapels, and gavit, prayers rose, treatises were written, and spirituality was nurtured. Khachkars of the 12th–13th centuries nearby remind us: steadfast faith is our national fortress.

name: St. George Cathedral (Surb Gevorg), Tbilisi
description: The Surb Gevorg Cathedral, a 13th-century Armenian church, stands in the heart of old Tbilisi near Narikala Fortress. Its longevity is a living memory of the continuous Armenian spiritual presence. Within its holy walls prayerful tradition meets art, still being restored today to lead us on the path of repentance, hope, and fellowship.

name: Holy Mother of God Church (Surb Astvatsatsin), Baku
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Baku, built in the late 18th–19th centuries near the Maiden Tower, was one of two stone Armenian churches in the city alongside Surb Grigor Cathedral. It could still be seen in photographs during Soviet times, but was finally destroyed in the early 1990s. Only the lower tier of the bell tower remains.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church (Surb Grigor Lusavorich)
description: Built between 1863–1869 to the design of architect Karl Gustav Hippius, this Armenian Apostolic church stood near Fountain Square. It was one of the few Armenian sanctuaries to survive in Baku. During Soviet times it was repurposed, and in 2002 it was handed over to serve as a library repository. It no longer functions as a church but remains a monument of architecture.

name: Cathedral of Sts. Thaddeus and Bartholomew
description: The Armenian cathedral in Baku, dedicated to the Apostles Thaddeus and Bartholomew, was demolished in 1934 during the Soviet anti-religious campaign. Before its destruction it was the main spiritual center of the Armenian community of the city.

name: St. Hovhannes Mkrtich Church
description: The Church of St. Hovhannes Mkrtich (St. John the Baptist) in Baku was built by the Armenian community and served as the district’s spiritual center. In the 1930s it was demolished by the Soviet authorities, and its building materials were reused for the Azerbaijan Drama Theater. Today the church no longer survives, though its memory remains an important part of the Armenian heritage of the city.

name: St. Hovhannes Church, Ganja
description: This Armenian Apostolic church was founded in 1633, according to an inscription at the entrance, and later restored in 1860. Until the 1990s it remained active. After the anti-Armenian pogroms the local community ceased to exist, the church lost its crosses and Armenian inscriptions, and it was converted into a music club.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Ganja
description: This Armenian Apostolic church was founded on September 14, 1853 and consecrated on November 9, 1869 by Archbishop Makar, head of Georgia and Imereti. The church was monumental in size: about 30.5 m long and 19.7 m wide, with four columns, three entrances, and a decorative fence with stone angels and wrought iron gates. A parish school for both boys and girls operated here. Today the building no longer functions as a church but remains an important historical and architectural monument.

name: St. Sargis Church, Ganja
description: This 18th-century Armenian Apostolic church stood by the Armenian cemetery in the Norshen district of Ganja. Initially a small prayer site, mentioned in documents of 1881, it was restored after the destruction of 1905–1906 by Nikoghayos Ghukasyants and reconsecrated on June 4, 1917. In Soviet times it was turned into a ‘Palace of Friendship of Peoples’. Today the building has been refurbished in Turkish style and is used as a museum.

name: St. Stepanos Church, Pip
description: The Church of St. Stepanos in Pip was built in the 19th century, completed in 1849, with its bell tower erected in 1847 funded by Stepan Mirimyants. It was a single-domed basilica about 22 m long and 12 m wide, with six interior columns and a western entrance. It was an important spiritual center for local Armenians, housing handwritten Gospels and inscriptions. In 1928 it was closed by Soviet authorities, and after the expulsion of Armenians in the late 20th century it lost its function. Used as a barn for years, it fell into ruin. Today it has not survived, though its memory remains part of the Armenian spiritual heritage of Gandzak and its surroundings.

name: St. Pepronia Church, Pip
description: Dedicated to St. Pepronia the Virgin, this church stood in the historic Gardman district (Pip area) of Dashkesan. It was the settlement’s main shrine, built in the style of medieval Armenian double-domed churches with thick walls and vaults. Dimensions: about 26.35 m by 12.70 m, wall thickness 2.40 m. The church had two arched coverings and secret niches near the altar. By the late 20th century it lost its function after Armenians were expelled; its present state is unknown.

name: Charek Monastery (Charek Vank)
address: ≈10 km from Pip village, Dashkesan District, Azerbaijan
description: Also known as Charekavank or Chareka-anapat, this monastery in the Gardman district of Greater Armenia was founded in the 17th century by Bishop David (Garamanian from Shamkhor). The complex included the Church of the Holy Mother of God (a three-nave basilica, 17.28 × 9.72 m), a gavit, a bell tower (1659), Harants chapel, refectory, and monastic cells. It was repeatedly destroyed and rebuilt, and held extensive land. After Soviet power the monastery’s lands were confiscated and a Turkish Hanafi family settled there. Today the ruins are semi-destroyed, used as a livestock yard by local Turkish-Kurdish shepherds.

name: Charek Monastery (Kharants Vank)
address: ≈1 km NE of Böyük Qaramurad village, Getabek District, Azerbaijan
description: Also known as Böyük Qaramurad Vank, this 12th-century Armenian monastery stood on a hill between two gorges. It included a hewn-stone church (≈15 × 9.6 m), a bell tower on the NE corner, and a stone cross on a pedestal beside it. The church was repeatedly restored: manuscripts were copied here in 1659, 1679, and 1682. Today the complex is partly ruined; the church and bell tower survive in fragments, used by locals as a cattle yard.

name: Monastery of the Translators (Surb Targmanchats Vank)
address: ≈4 km north of Dashkesan (Khachakap / Quşçu), Azerbaijan
description: Founded in the late 4th–early 5th century by St. Mesrop Mashtots and Sahak Partev, this monastery was a cradle of Armenian literacy. Located at 1315 m elevation on a scenic slope, its main cross-domed church with gavit and bell tower was restored in 989 and again in 1845. Here Gospels and historic documents were stored, and by tradition the first Armenian translations were made. It functioned until the early 20th century, later abandoned. Today walls, monk cells, basements, and architectural fragments remain visible.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Banants
description: Built between 1863–1866 by Banants villagers, this Armenian Apostolic church stood beside the older Surb Astvatsatsin and was known as the ‘new’ church. Size: 27.9 × 13.3 m. Simple and harmonious architecture. It functioned until the 1990s, after which it was abandoned and desecrated following the expulsion of Armenians. Today it lies semi-ruined, with a state flag placed on its roof, and is officially listed as ‘Albanian’ cultural heritage.

name: St. Karapet Church, Aprakunis
address: Near Aprakunis village (now Nakhchivan AR), Azerbaijan
description: Founded in the late 14th century by Malakia from Crimea and completed by his disciple Grigor Tatevatsi in 1386, this monastery served as a major spiritual and cultural center in the 14th–18th centuries with a school, manuscripts, and relics. In the 17th century new structures were added: a four-domed church, gavit, and bell tower. The interior contained frescoes, khachkars, and inscriptions. By the early 20th century it ceased to function and after the Armenian expulsion was destroyed. Only ruins remain today.

name: St. Elishe (Kish) Church
address: Kish village, ≈5 km north of Sheki, Azerbaijan
description: Also known as the Church of St. Elishe or Holy Mother of God, this ancient Christian shrine stands in Kish, near Sheki. Likely built in the early 12th century, it has belonged to Georgian Orthodox, then to Albanian, and later Armenian Apostolic traditions. Archaeological digs (2000–2003) revealed cult layers under the altar dating to 3000 BC. The current structure dates to ca. 990–1160 AD.

name: Mesrop Mashtots Monastery (Surb Grigor Lusavorich), Nesirvas
address: Nesirvas village, Ordubad District, Nakhchivan AR, Azerbaijan
description: Founded in 456 by Prince Shabit of Goghtn, this Armenian Apostolic monastery included a domed church with hall, altar, forechurch, bell tower, and residence. It was repeatedly restored in the 15th–19th centuries. Partly standing until the late 20th century, it was completely destroyed by 2006, as documented by satellite research.

name: Holy Mother of God Monastery (Surb Astvatsatsin), Channab
address: Channab village, Ordubad District, Nakhchivan AR, Azerbaijan
description: Rebuilt in the late 12th century and renovated in the 16th–17th, this Armenian cross-domed basilica had a bright apse, two sacristies, and a dome on four cruciform pillars. A bell tower adjoined its south façade, decorated with Armenian inscriptions and sculptures. Still intact in the 1980s, by February 3, 2000 it was completely destroyed, as confirmed by satellite evidence. Nearby stood an Armenian cemetery with 180–200 tombstones, also erased by that date.

name: Holy Saviour Monastery, Julfa
address: NW of Julfa cemetery, Nakhchivan AR, Azerbaijan
description: Founded no later than the 9th–10th centuries, this monastery was mentioned in 976 under King Ashot the Pious. Possibly earlier, perhaps in the reign of Khachik II or in 1271 by Baron Vahram. It stood above the Araxes near Myakharda ridge. Survived until the 1980s, but between 1997–2003 it was destroyed during the campaign against Armenian heritage. The Julfa cemetery with 47 tombs was also obliterated by 2003.

name: St. Kristapor Church, Upper Aylis
address: Upper Aylis village (Yukhari Aylis), Nakhchivan AR, Azerbaijan
description: The Church of St. Kristapor was an Armenian Apostolic church located on Gindar hill in central Upper Aylis. First mentioned in the 15th century, it was restored in 1671–1675 according to Armenian inscriptions. Architecturally it was a domed basilica with four naves, including sanctuary, storage, and a prayer hall with large windows. It had three decorated arched entrances: west, north, and south. Still standing in the 1980s, it was completely destroyed by February 3, 2000, as confirmed by satellite studies. Today nothing remains, yet its memory survives as part of the Armenian heritage of Aylis.

name: St. Hakob-Hayrapet Church, Shurud
address: Shurud village, Julfa District, Nakhchivan AR, Azerbaijan
description: Built in the 12th century in central Shurud, this Armenian Apostolic church was a cruciform basilica with a tall conical dome visible from afar. Its facades bore Armenian inscriptions and frescoes, with 17th-century khachkars above the entrances. The dome was painted by artist Naghash Ovnatanyan in the 1680s. The church was destroyed between 1997 and June 15, 2006, as confirmed by satellite evidence.

name: St. Sarkis Monastery of Gag
address: Gag Mountain, ~500 m east of today’s Armenia border, Azerbaijan
description: A medieval Armenian Apostolic monastery located on the summit of Mount Gag at ~922 m altitude. Tradition holds it was founded by St. Mesrop Mashtots, who buried part of St. Sarkis’s skull here, attested by ancient Armenian hymns. Inscriptions and records note renovations, including in 1851 by mason Yesayi Nurinyants under patron Sargis Varshamyan. Known as a pilgrimage and educational center, its remains survive only in fragments, with many inscriptions deliberately erased.

name: Khachin-Darbatli Mausoleum
address: Khachin-Dorbatly village, Aghdam District (historic Artsakh), Azerbaijan
description: Built in 1314 by Armenian architect Vardapet Shahik, this 12-sided mausoleum is a rare example of medieval Armenian architecture in Artsakh, blending Armenian style with Islamic ornamental elements. Connected to the princely house of Khachin, it stood as a symbol of Armenian aristocracy and heritage. Despite conflicts and destruction in the 20th century, surveys in 2023 confirmed it survived relatively intact. For Armenians it remains testimony of centuries of presence and culture in Artsakh.

name: Vankasar Church
address: On Vankasar hilltop, Askeran District (historic Artsakh / de jure Aghdam District), Azerbaijan
description: The Vankasar Church, dating from the 7th century, stood atop a mountain ridge, visible for kilometers as a symbol of spiritual permanence. First documented in 1858, Archbishop Sargis Jalalyants described it as ‘monastery ruins’. In the 1980s restoration erased Armenian inscriptions and khachkars. Damaged in the First Karabakh War but later restored by Artsakh authorities. After the 2020s it fell under Azerbaijani control; in 2024 video evidence showed its cross removed. For Armenians it is not just architecture but a spiritual beacon of Artsakh.

name: Dadivank Monastery
address: Mountains near Terter river valley, historic Khachen, Azerbaijan
description: One of the greatest monuments of Armenian spirituality, founded between the 9th–13th centuries over the tomb of St. Dadi. Until 2020 it functioned as a monastic center of Artsakh’s diocese. After the 2020 war it came under Russian peacekeepers, later under Azerbaijani police. Armenian clergy were gradually expelled. By late 2024 it was handed to the Udi community and ceased as an Armenian Apostolic shrine. For Armenians Dadivank remains a symbol of millennial faith and cultural continuity in Artsakh.

name: Amaras Monastery
address: Near Sos village, historic Artsakh (now Aghdam District), Azerbaijan
description: Founded in the 4th century by St. Gregory the Illuminator over the tomb of his grandson St. Grigoris, Amaras was site of Armenia’s first school, opened by Mesrop Mashtots in the 5th century. Through centuries it served as a bishopric, fortified with walls, and was rebuilt many times. Revived after Artsakh’s liberation, it ceased after late 2023 when the region fell under Azerbaijani control. Armenian crosses were removed and clergy forced out. For Armenians Amaras is forever a symbol of literacy and roots.

name: Gtichavank Monastery
address: Northern slope of Toghasar Mountain, near Togh village, historic Dizak, Azerbaijan
description: Built 1241–1246 by Bishops Sargis and Vrtanes of Amaras over ruins of an older center, Gtichavank was a major spiritual and cultural hub of Dizak. The complex had a domed main church, a smaller northern church with sacristies under the altar, schools, library, and khachkars. Flourished in the 13th–18th centuries, patronized by Dizak’s meliks. Restored in the late 20th century, but since 2020 no longer under Armenian control. For Armenians, Gtichavank is a proud monument of faith and continuity.

name: Katarovank Monastery
address: Mount Dizapayt, near Hin Tagher village, Hadrut District, Azerbaijan
description: Founded in the 4th century and mentioned by historian Pavstos Buzand, Katarovank was once one of the greatest sanctuaries of Artsakh. Children of St. Grigoris were said to have fled here with his relics. A stone chapel built in the 17th century preserved memory until modern times. Though inactive by the 20th century, it survived as a symbol of continuity. During the war it briefly functioned as a stronghold, later lost. Today it is no longer an Armenian shrine but a reminder of millennial endurance.

name: St. John the Baptist Church, Martakert
address: Martakert town (Tartar District, historic Artsakh), Azerbaijan
description: Built in 1883, this Armenian Apostolic church was Martakert’s spiritual heart. Restored in 2003, it remained active until recent years. The adjacent cemetery with priests’ tombs bore historic memory. After the 2023 expulsion of Armenians from Artsakh, the church fell under Azerbaijani control.

name: Yerits Mankants Monastery
address: Mountains west of Maghavuz, near Tonashen and Jraberd fortress, Martakert, Azerbaijan
description: Built in 1691 by the melik Israelian family of Jraberd, Yerits Mankants was rival to Gandzasar. The basilica had a dome supported by four cruciform pillars, with sacristy, refectory, monastic quarters, and cemetery with khachkars dating to 14th–16th centuries. It sheltered refugees during the war, later partly restored, but again abandoned. Today it no longer functions, though it remains a vivid witness of Armenian Artsakh.

name: Cathedral of the Holy Mother of God, Stepanakert
description: Consecrated in 2019 after 13 years of construction, this cathedral became the eparchial center of Artsakh. During the 2020 war it sheltered civilians. The last liturgy was served October 1, 2023, after which it ceased to function under Armenian clergy. For Armenians it symbolizes resilience and faith, even in exile.

name: Agulecots Holy Mother of God Church, Shushi
description: Known as Agulecots (‘church of Aylis settlers’), this Armenian church was built in 1822 by nobles of the Ter-Matevos-Tarumyan family from Aylis. It was Shushi’s main church until Ghazanchetsots was built. A domed hall with cross-shaped exterior and three entrances, rotunda bell tower, and two-story side chapels. Destroyed in the 1960s and replaced with a school. Only archaeological remains preserve its memory as the lost spiritual and cultural heart of Shushi’s Armenians.

name: St. John the Baptist Church, Byurakan
description: Surb Hovhannes Mkrtich in Byurakan is a majestic 10th-century basilica. With two entrances, narrow windows, and a Maltese-cross facade, it is surrounded by khachkars that stand as witnesses of faith. Inside is silence and grace, where ancient walls keep the prayers of generations. More than a building, it is a beacon of the Armenian Church on Aragats’s slopes.

name: Aghjots Monastery
description: Aghjots Vank, a 7th-century Armenian monastery, now lies in ruins along the gorge between Garni and Geghard. The main church was dedicated to St. John the Baptist, with a basilica, apse, carved portal, cells, and auxiliary buildings. Abandoned in Soviet times, parts collapsed. Today it is a reminder of unbroken spiritual tradition and prayerful memory.

name: Kobayr Monastery
address: Above Debed gorge, near Tumanyan, Lori Province, Armenia
description: Founded in 1171 by Princess Mariam of the Kyurikid dynasty, later passing to the Zakarian house, Kobayr flourished as a spiritual center in the 12th–13th centuries. Known for frescoes in Byzantine-Georgian style and a belfry-mausoleum, it was abandoned in the 19th–20th centuries. Partial restorations began in the 20th and 21st centuries. It is a fragile yet living memory of Armenian spirituality.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Kurtan
description: Built in the 5th century, this is one of the earliest stone churches of the region. A single-nave basilica with three entrances, horseshoe apse, and early medieval windows, it was partly destroyed in the 20th century but restored in 1982–84 and re-consecrated in 2017. Today it remains a spiritual beacon of Lori.

name: Arichavank Monastery
description: A jewel of Armenian architecture (7th–13th cc.), Arichavank consists of St. Grigor (7th c.), St. Astvatsatsin (1201), and a grand gavit (1224). Once a seminary and Catholicos’s summer residence, its multicolored tuff walls are adorned with carvings, sirens, doves, and symbolic miniatures. For Armenians it is a living stone of memory and prayer.

name: Holy Saviour Church, Gyumri
address: Vardanants Square, Gyumri, Shirak Province, Armenia
description: Built 1858–1872 by architect Tadevos Andikyan, consecrated in 1873, Surb Amenaprkich resembles Ani Cathedral but larger. Nationalized in Soviet times, its belfry destroyed in 1932, later rebuilt in 1964. Damaged in 1988 Spitak earthquake, restored in the 2000s, and re-consecrated in 2024. Today it stands as a symbol of rebirth.

name: Cathedral of St. Gregory the Illuminator, Goris
description: Built 1897–1904, consecrated in 1903, this cathedral was closed in Soviet years, turned into a granary and museum, then restored and re-consecrated in 1989. Its gray tuff walls keep prayers of generations, and its yard gathers khachkars and stones from the 10th–18th centuries.

name: Aghartsin Monastery
description: Aghartsin (11th–13th cc.) enchants with St. Grigor, St. Astvatsatsin (1281), St. Stepanos (1244), refectory, treasury, and royal tombs of the Kyurikids. Known for carved eagles, khachkars, and forest setting. For Armenians it unites stone prayer with forest hymn.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Vardenis
description: Built in 1905, surrounded by 14th–17th-century khachkars, this church became the spiritual center of the city. Historian Hovhannes Tsaretsi once served here, giving it cultural significance as well.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Gavar
description: Built in 1905 of finely hewn stone blocks under Bishop Khoren I, this cross-domed church is a symbol of Gavar’s faith and identity. Surrounded by old khachkars and inscriptions, its dome rises above the city. Today it remains one of the region’s main churches.

name: St. Grigor Narekatsi Church, Vanadzor
description: A modern Armenian Apostolic church, built in the early 21st century, dedicated to St. Grigor Narekatsi, poet and theologian. Its traditional style with dome and stone cladding harmonizes with Lori’s landscape. Today it is Vanadzor’s spiritual center, hosting liturgies, schools, and cultural programs.

name: St. John Church, Sohrol
address: Sohrol village, Shabestar District, East Azerbaijan, Iran
description: An Armenian Catholic church, originally from the 5th–6th c., rebuilt in brick in 1840 by General Samson Khan and patron Hagubov. It had three domes: an octagonal belfry, a conical dome, and a smaller octagonal dome over the altar. Damaged by earthquake in 1936, closed, listed as Iranian heritage in 1968. Repairs in 2020 stabilized the structure.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Darashamb
description: A rare 17th-century Armenian sanctuary in the Araxes valley near Nakhichevan, dedicated to the Holy Mother of God. Now in ruins, it remains a marker of Armenian presence.

name: St. Thaddeus Monastery (Qareh Kelisa)
address: Chaldoran District, West Azerbaijan Province, Iran
description: Also known as the ‘Black Church’, this is one of Armenia’s oldest monasteries, where St. Thaddeus is said to be buried. The current church dates to 1329 after an earthquake, with major 19th-c. restorations under Prince Abbas Mirza. Listed by UNESCO, it hosts annual pilgrimages in July.

name: St. Stepanos Monastery, Darashamb
address: Right bank of Araxes near abandoned Darashamb, East Azerbaijan, Iran
description: A 9th-century Armenian monastery in historic Vaspurakan, later rebuilt in the 17th century with belfry, refectory, and carvings. Though no longer active, it remains a symbol of Armenia’s spiritual legacy.

name: St. Sarkis Cathedral, Tehran
address: Intersection of Karimkhan Zand and Nejatollahi (formerly Villa Street), Tehran, Iran
description: The Surb Sarkis Cathedral is the seat of the Armenian Apostolic Church in Tehran, built by the Sarkisian brothers in memory of their parents. Construction began in 1964 and was completed in 1970, consecrated in 1973. It is the largest Armenian church in Tehran, built in basilica style with a single nave, clad in white marble. The dome was originally suspended on the walls but later reinforced by four columns. The facade is crowned with twin bell towers with octagonal domes. Inside are a choir gallery, altar with biblical frescoes, and a 3.5 m marble memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide of 1915 in the courtyard.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Tabriz
description: Surb Astvatsatsin, completed in 1785 on the site of a 12th-century church mentioned by Marco Polo, is the largest and oldest Christian sanctuary of Tabriz. It long served as the cathedral of the Atrpatakan diocese. Located in the Dik-Bashi district, it is cross-domed with four massive stone columns supporting the dome. The area also houses church buildings and the Tabriz Armenian Museum. It was the spiritual center of Iran’s Armenians for centuries.

name: St. Sarkis Church, Tabriz
address: Baron-Avak (Lilava) district, Tabriz, East Azerbaijan, Iran
description: Built in 1821 by the Petrosyan family, this cruciform Armenian Apostolic church was restored in 1845. Its stone walls, brick dome, and three entrances reflect Armenian architectural tradition blended with the local setting. It remains a symbol of continuity of faith for Tabriz Armenians. The Tamaryan school complex and Sahakyan center are adjacent, and a memorial to Armenian martyrs stands in its courtyard.

name: St. Shoghakat Chapel, Tabriz
description: This 17th-century chapel, part of the Atrpatakan diocese, stands in the Armenian cemetery of Tabriz. Dedicated to the martyrs Hripsime and Gayane, it became a vital spiritual site especially in difficult times. It remains active today, serving the Armenian community of Tabriz.

name: Holy Mother of God Chapel, Tabriz
address: Maralan district, Tabriz, East Azerbaijan, Iran
description: Mariam Nane Chapel, built around 1776 in basilica style, replaced a 16th-century church destroyed by an earthquake in 1721. Its clay-and-brick walls are unplastered inside, with eastern entrance and iconographic windows on north and south sides. Nearby, a new cemetery chapel was founded in the 19th century, but Mariam Nane preserves ties with earlier generations. It remains a spiritual center, especially during Transfiguration feasts with blessing of grapes.

name: Holy Cross Church, Mets Pamaj
description: This 18th-century Armenian Apostolic church is a 25×15 m basilica with a dome on an octagonal drum, built of large cut stones. Surrounded by khachkars and tombstones of the 18th–19th cc., it exemplifies rural Armenian architecture. Still active, it serves as a place of prayer for the region’s Armenians.

name: St. John Church, Maragheh
description: Originally founded in the 5th–6th cc., the current building was erected in 1840 under General Samson Khan with Russian and French architects. The complex includes the archbishop’s residence, a school, and a candle hall. Though partly abandoned after Armenian migration, it retains spiritual and historical significance. Restoration in 2020 reinforced its walls and facade.

name: St. Shepherd Chapel
address: 8 km NW of Julfa, East Azerbaijan, Iran
description: Built in 1518 on the rocky right bank of the Araxes, this small chapel commemorates two shepherd brothers. Constructed in the Safavid basilica style, it belongs to the Atrpatakan diocese. Restored in 1836, it remains active today, guiding pilgrims to nearby monasteries of Darashamb and St. Stepanos.

name: Dzor-Dzor Monastery (Holy Mother of God)
description: Dating to the 10th (or 14th) century, only its small chapel survives. Part of the UNESCO-listed Armenian Monastic Ensembles of Iran, it exemplifies Armenian architecture and art abroad. Today it stands as a silent witness to Armenian spiritual presence.

name: St. Gevorg Church, Haftvan
address: Haftvan village, Salmas District, West Azerbaijan, Iran
description: Dating to the 13th century, this church was restored in 1652 and again after the 1930 earthquake. Its massive stone walls, domed roof, and austere interior reflect Armenian prayer tradition. Still active, it symbolizes centuries of perseverance of faith and identity.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Tehran
address: Between Masoud-e-Saad St. and Mirza Kuchak Khan St., near Jomhouri-e Eslami Ave., Tehran, Iran
description: Surb Astvatsatsin, laid in 1938 and completed in 1945, was designed by Nikolai Lauri and finished by architect Nikolai Markov. Built in 7th–10th century Armenian style from gray basalt, it is cross-domed with two domes. It served as the Archbishop’s residence (1945–1970) and was listed as a national monument in 2002. Nearby stands the Archbishop Ardak Manoukian Museum, preserving Armenian ecclesiastical heritage.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Tehran
description: Built in 1982 in cross-domed basilica style, this Armenian Apostolic church belongs to the Tehran diocese of the Cilician Catholicosate. It continues to serve as a spiritual center for Tehran’s Armenians.

name: St. Gevorg Church, Tehran
address: Darkhungah Alley, Sangilaj District, Tehran, Iran
description: Originally a small chapel built in 1795 by Armenians resettled from Tbilisi and Artsakh, the current building dates to 1882–1884. In Armenian cross-domed style, with an octagonal drum and a southern bell tower, it is Tehran’s second oldest Armenian sanctuary. Beneath it lie notable burials including artist Hakob Hovnatanian and General Martiros Davidkhanian. Registered as a national monument (#1621), it remains active.

name: Church of the Holy Translators, Tehran
address: Vahideh District, Madraseh Aramane St., Tehran, Iran
description: Consecrated in November 1968, built as a cross-shaped basilica with a dome on a cylindrical drum and a pyramid roof. Dedicated to the disciples of Mesrop Mashtots, it features frescoes and an eight-sided belfry. In its courtyard stands a bust of Mesrop by artist Lilit Teryan. It serves as a center of prayer and cultural memory for Tehran’s Armenians.

name: St. Mesrop Church, Mashhad
address: Khorasan Street, near Imam Khomeini Metro, Mashhad, Iran
description: Built in 1941, it is the only Armenian Apostolic church in Mashhad. Cross-basilica with two conical domes, one topped by an iron cross. It once held a library of 1,000 volumes. Registered as a national heritage site in 2005, restored in 2017, it remains a symbol of Armenian presence in the region.

name: St. Mesrop Church, Rasht
address: Saadi Street, opposite former governor’s office, Rasht, Gilan, Iran
description: Built in the late Qajar period and completed in 1954 in Pahlavi style. The present church was laid after a fire destroyed the old one in 1920, and consecrated in 1966 by Archbishop Hovhannes Hovhanian. Listed as a national cultural monument (#21523). It remains active for Rasht’s Armenians.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Bandar-e Anzali
address: Imam Khomeini Square, Motahari Ave., Bandar-e Anzali, Gilan, Iran
description: Built in 1885 by an Armenian family during the Qajar era. Rectangular, east–west oriented, with three entrances and a bell tower dome supported by six columns. Declared for restoration in 2023. It remains a living testimony of Armenian presence in Anzali.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Hamadan
description: Founded in 1676 by Armenians resettled from Eastern Armenia, it was the first church of Hamadan’s Armenian community. It served not only the city but surrounding villages. Still active today, it symbolizes enduring faith and cultural continuity.

name: Holy Savior Cathedral, New Julfa (Isfahan)
description: Founded c.1606, completed in 1664 under Archbishop David. It fuses Armenian cross-domed style with Persian miniatures: frescoes, gilded carvings, a dome with Creation and Paradise scenes. Its courtyard houses a bell tower and the Khachatur Kesaratsi Museum. It remains the crown of Armenian spirituality and art in Iran.

name: St. Karapet Church, Abadan
address: Near Imam Musa ibn Jafar Mosque, Abadan, Khuzestan, Iran
description: Built in 1958 in Pahlavi style with a domed rectangular plan. Damaged in the Iran–Iraq war, restored in the 1990s, and registered as a national monument (#8352). It stands as a reminder of Armenian presence in Abadan.

name: St. Mesrop Church, Ahvaz
address: Shahid Mostafa St., Ahvaz, Khuzestan, Iran
description: Consecrated in 1968, initiated by architect Trdat Davtyan. It included a church, school, hall, and clergy house. Damaged in the revolution and war, it remains a silent witness of Armenian cultural presence.

name: St. Mary Church, Shiraz
address: Sang-e Siah district, Shiraz, Fars, Iran
description: Built in 1662 under Shah Abbas II, replacing a mid-16th c. chapel. Without a dome, it has a flat-roofed hall flanked by two-story galleries. Its painted wooden ceiling in turquoise and gold is a jewel of Safavid art. Damaged by earthquakes, restored in 2020s. Usually closed, it opens on special days for Armenians and pilgrims.

name: Armenian Patriarchate of Constantinople (Cathedral of the Holy Mother of God), Istanbul
description: Founded in 1461 by Sultan Mehmed II, the Armenian Patriarchate of Constantinople remains the spiritual center of Armenians in Turkey. Its seat is in the Cathedral of the Holy Mother of God in Kumkapı. Despite 20th-century upheavals, it continues to serve as the heart of Armenian church life in Istanbul.

name: Ermenčik Monastery
description: The Ermenčik Monastery, dedicated to Archangels Gabriel and Michael, was founded in the late 14th century by Armenians who settled after the Battle of Kosovo. Two legends exist: one tells of Armenian soldiers switching sides to Christians and founding the monastery; another of monks fleeing persecution. Once home to 400 monks, it was destroyed and rebuilt many times. Today only the church of the Archangels survives, used annually on July 26 for the feast of Archangel Gabriel.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church (Abughamrents), Ani
description: Built around 980 by Prince Grigor Pahlavuni or his wife Shushanik, this small but well-preserved 10th-century Armenian church later became the Pahlavuni family mausoleum. Unique for its six-apse rotunda under a domed drum, its facade once showed traces of red and cream paint. Looted in the 1990s, it remains a fine example of Ani’s late 10th–11th c. revival.

name: Church of the Holy Savior (Surb Prkich), Ani
address: 300 m east of Ani Cathedral, Ani, Turkey
description: Built in 1035 by Prince Abulgharib Pahlavuni to house a relic of the True Cross. With a 19-sided foundation and tall cylindrical drum, it combines monumentality with intricate detailing. Frescoes of Christ and the Evangelists survive beneath whitewash. Damaged by storms (1957) and the 1988 earthquake, it remains part of Ani’s UNESCO World Heritage ensemble.

name: Church of the Holy Cross (Surb Khach), Akhtamar
description: Built 915–921 by monk-architect Manuel under King Gagik Artsruni as a palace chapel. Famous for its rich biblical reliefs on the facade, including Old and New Testament scenes. Abandoned after 1915, restored in 2007, it now functions as a museum with one liturgy annually in September. It remains a cultural and artistic treasure of Armenian heritage.

name: St. Kirakos Church, Diyarbakır
description: One of the largest Armenian churches in the Middle East, with capacity for 1,400–3,000. Originally built c.1376, rebuilt in the 16th c., its bell tower once dominated the skyline. Confiscated in WWI, used as depot and factory, restored 2009–2011 with diaspora support, reopened in 2011. Damaged in 2016 fighting, returned to Armenians in 2022 and reopened for worship.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, Kayseri
address: Tacettinveli Mah., Topaç Sok. 5, Kayseri, Turkey
description: Founded in 1191, rebuilt in 1653 and renovated several times. A three-nave basilica with a domed drum. Restored in the late 20th–early 21st century, it again serves worshippers and preserves Armenian spiritual heritage in Kayseri.

name: Church of the Holy Apostles (Surb Arakelots), Kars
address: Below Kars Fortress, Kaleiçi, Kars, Turkey
description: Built 931–942 by King Abas I Bagratuni as a domed tetraconch. Reliefs of the Twelve Apostles decorate its drum. Converted to a mosque (16th c.), Orthodox cathedral, museum, and back to a mosque in 1993. Today it forms part of a major Islamic complex.

name: Holy Mother of God Church, Gaziantep
address: Tepebaşı district, Kıymet Tepe, Gaziantep, Turkey
description: Built 1892–1893 by architect Sarkis Balyan and mason Sarkis Tasciyan as the main Armenian cathedral of Gaziantep. Looted and closed in 1915, later converted into a prison, then into Kurtuluş Mosque (1984–1986). Preserves Gothic–Neoclassical Armenian architecture with arched and circular windows and a hipped roof.

name: Monastery of St. Bartholomew, Albayrak (Van)
address: Albayrak (historic Aghbak), Başkale district, Van Province, Turkey
description: Traditionally built over the tomb of Apostle Bartholomew, sources differ on its founding: by King Sanatruk (2nd c.) or St. Gregory the Illuminator (4th c.). First mentioned in 10th c., known as the Apostle’s Monastery from 1316. Once a spiritual center with scriptorium and 30 monks. Damaged over centuries, destroyed by the Turkish army in the 1960s. Plans for restoration announced in 2011 remain unrealized.

name: Eghgnamor Monastery (Holy Mother of God Church)
description: Eghgnamor Monastery, also known as the Church of the Holy Mother of God, was one of the most significant medieval Armenian monastic complexes in the Kars region. Founded in the early Middle Ages, it served as a spiritual center of the local community. Built of cut stone, it featured a domed composition typical of Armenian ecclesiastical architecture. Over centuries, it functioned as a place of pilgrimage and learning, with manuscripts copied and theology cultivated. Abandoned after the Armenian Genocide, it fell into ruin. Today only picturesque remains survive, bearing witness to its former significance.

name: Karmravank Monastery
address: Southern shore of Lake Van, Gevaş District, Van Province, Turkey
description: Karmravank, the 'Red Monastery,' was founded in the 10th century by King Gagik I Artsruni. It was named for its reliquary adorned with red jewels and containing a relic of the True Cross. The complex included two churches (mainly Surb Astvatsatsin) and a defensive wall. Under the Aghtamar Catholicosate until the 19th c., it was plundered in 1895. Today only ruins remain.

name: Amenaprkich (Holy Savior) Monastery, Trabzon
description: Founded in 1424 by Stepan Baghdasar, this monastery combined medieval Armenian architecture with local features. Known also as Kaymaklı Monastery, legend tells of a builder’s miraculous survival after falling from its dome, giving it the name 'All Savior.' Frescoes with biblical scenes decorated its walls. Once the episcopal seat of Trabzon, it was abandoned after 1915 and left in ruin. Remains of its main church and a small chapel survive as reminders of centuries of Armenian presence.

name: Varzahan Monastery
description: A large Armenian monastic complex dating to the 10th–12th centuries. It reportedly contained three central churches: an octagonal, a gate church, and a cross-domed basilica, as well as a cemetery with ram-shaped tombstones. Noted by travelers like Austen Henry Layard (1849) and photographed in 1911, it was fully destroyed by the mid-20th century. Today nothing remains but descriptions and archival images.

name: Church of the Holy Apostles, Ani
description: Built in 1031 by the Pahlavuni family, this cross-domed church with four apses once held inscriptions noting land donations. The central dome was surrounded by small domes on corner niches, typical of the 11th century. The southern porch survived better and was reinforced by archaeologist Marr in the early 20th century. Most of the church was later destroyed under Turkish rule.

name: Agperig Monastery (St. Thaddeus), Sasun
address: Sasun Mountains, 20 km SE of Mush, Turkey
description: Also known as Agperkavank, this monastery was famed for its sacred spring, said to have been blessed by Apostle Thaddeus with one of Christ’s crucifixion nails. Its complex included St. Thaddeus Church (pre-10th c.), St. Stephen’s Chapel, and the Savior’s Church (mid-10th c.) built by Prince Viken Mamikonian. It was a place of learning and pilgrimage until the early 20th century. Attacks in 1899 and 1908 killed abbots, and in 1914 monks and students were massacred during the Armenian Genocide. Today only ruins remain.

name: Holy Mother of God Monastery, Arapgir
description: A large 13th-century Armenian monastery that could accommodate up to 3,000 people. It was looted and burned during the Armenian Genocide (1915) and later used as a school. In 1957 the municipality demolished it with dynamite, and the land was sold. Today only ruins remain as a reminder of its past significance.

name: Virgin's Monastery (Hripsime Nunnery), Ani
description: Built in the 13th century by Tigran Honents, this nunnery stood on a rocky promontory above the Akhuryan River. Only a fragment of the gate and the six-apse domed church remain. Its exterior featured elegant arcades, and the dome was topped by a multi-gabled umbrella roof—an architectural rarity in Ani. It was dedicated to the virgin martyrs led by Hripsime, possibly housing a community of nuns.

name: Cathedral of St. John the Baptist (Bagavan)
description: One of the largest Armenian churches of the 7th century, built between 631–639 by architect Israel of Odzun under Bishop Ezra. It was a royal spiritual center of Bagrevand Province: coronations and noble councils took place here, and tradition says Gregory the Illuminator baptized King Tiridates III here. Its vast basilica (46 × 27 m) was destroyed in 1877 and completely demolished after 1915.

name: Narekavank Monastery (St. Sandukht), Narek
description: A renowned 10th-century monastery where St. Gregory of Narek studied and wrote. Founded under Anania Narekatsi, it included the Church of St. Sandukht, Gregory’s mausoleum, and a library of illuminated manuscripts. Destroyed during the Armenian Genocide, in 1949 a mosque was built on its ruins.

name: Church of St. Marine, Mush
description: The only surviving Armenian church in Mush, dedicated to St. Marine. Used until 1915, then turned into a prison during the Armenian Genocide. Today it lies in ruins, but remains a memorial to the martyrs.

name: Holy Savior Monastery (Yerazgavors), Shirakavan
description: Founded by King Smbat I in the 9th century, this domed basilica served as a royal and spiritual seat. It was exempted from taxes by the Zakarians in the 13th century. By the 19th century its dome had collapsed. Destroyed after 1920, only traces remain.

name: Varagavank Monastery (Seven Churches)
description: Tradition says a relic of the True Cross was found here in 653. The complex contained seven churches and became the cultural heart of Vaspurakan. Burned during the Genocide of 1915, only ruins survive.

name: St. Nshan Monastery, Sivas
description: Founded around 1022 by King Senekerim Artsruni, it housed relics of the Cross and the tombstone of St. John Chrysostom. Once a center of learning with a vast library. Looted and destroyed during the Armenian Genocide; nothing remains.

name: Church of St. Stephen, Smyrna (Izmir)
description: The largest Armenian church of Izmir, originally built in the 16th century, rebuilt after the 1689 earthquake and again after fires. Burned in the Great Fire of Smyrna in 1922 with the Armenian quarter. No remains today.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator (Tigran Honents), Ani
description: Built in 1215 by merchant Tigran Honents, richly decorated with Byzantine-style frescoes depicting the life of Christ and St. Gregory. Exterior inscriptions glorify the patron. Partially restored in the 20th century.

name: Aparank Monastery (Holy Cross)
description: Founded in the 10th century as a reliquary of the True Cross. Contained multiple churches: Surb Karapet (950), Surb Astvatsatsin (983), St. Stephen, and Holy Apostles. Destroyed in the 20th century; ruins remain.

name: Lim Monastery (Limin Desert)
description: Founded before 884, rebuilt by Catholicos Zakaria in 1305. It once housed a scriptorium with 300 manuscripts. Destroyed in 1915; today only the narthex survives.

name: Armas Monastery (Holy Virgin Charkhapan), near Izmit
description: Founded in 1611 (possibly 1416). It housed a seminary, printing press, and the Charkhapan icon of the Virgin, a pilgrimage object. Destroyed after the Genocide in 1923–24; only foundations remain.

name: Holy Trinity Church, Sivrihisar
description: One of Anatolia’s largest Armenian churches, built 1650, restored in 1881. After 1915 it became a warehouse. Restored as a museum space in 2010.

name: St. Nicholas Church, Samsun
description: Built in 1840–49, center of the Armenian diocese with a school and journal. Destroyed in 1936; replaced by a school. No remains.

name: Virgin's Monastery (Hripsime Nunnery), Ani
description: Built in the 13th century by Tigran Honents, this nunnery stood on a rocky promontory above the Akhuryan River. Only a fragment of the gate and the six-apse domed church remain. Its exterior featured elegant arcades, and the dome was topped by a multi-gabled umbrella roof—an architectural rarity in Ani. It was dedicated to the virgin martyrs led by Hripsime, possibly housing a community of nuns.

name: Cathedral of St. John the Baptist (Bagavan)
description: One of the largest Armenian churches of the 7th century, built between 631–639 by architect Israel of Odzun under Bishop Ezra. It was a royal spiritual center of Bagrevand Province: coronations and noble councils took place here, and tradition says Gregory the Illuminator baptized King Tiridates III here. Its vast basilica (46 × 27 m) was destroyed in 1877 and completely demolished after 1915.

name: Narekavank Monastery (St. Sandukht), Narek
description: A renowned 10th-century monastery where St. Gregory of Narek studied and wrote. Founded under Anania Narekatsi, it included the Church of St. Sandukht, Gregory’s mausoleum, and a library of illuminated manuscripts. Destroyed during the Armenian Genocide, in 1949 a mosque was built on its ruins.

name: Church of St. Marine, Mush
description: The only surviving Armenian church in Mush, dedicated to St. Marine. Used until 1915, then turned into a prison during the Armenian Genocide. Today it lies in ruins, but remains a memorial to the martyrs.

name: Holy Savior Monastery (Yerazgavors), Shirakavan
description: Founded by King Smbat I in the 9th century, this domed basilica served as a royal and spiritual seat. It was exempted from taxes by the Zakarians in the 13th century. By the 19th century its dome had collapsed. Destroyed after 1920, only traces remain.

name: Varagavank Monastery (Seven Churches)
description: Tradition says a relic of the True Cross was found here in 653. The complex contained seven churches and became the cultural heart of Vaspurakan. Burned during the Genocide of 1915, only ruins survive.

name: St. Nshan Monastery, Sivas
description: Founded around 1022 by King Senekerim Artsruni, it housed relics of the Cross and the tombstone of St. John Chrysostom. Once a center of learning with a vast library. Looted and destroyed during the Armenian Genocide; nothing remains.

name: Monastery of St. Hakob (Surb Hakob), Achn
description: The Monastery of St. Hakob (Surb Hakob) was founded in 1004 by Bishop Khachatur, as recorded in an inscription found during dome restoration in 1900. It became the main educational and spiritual center of Achn before schools were built, training future catholicoi, bishops, and priests, and preserving manuscripts. Built of finely cut stone with a rectangular plan, parts of its western and northern walls (1.5–2 m high) remain, while the eastern façade is largely intact. The monastery symbolizes the spiritual strength of Armenians in Cilicia and the preservation of sacred knowledge. Its ruins remind us of the great tradition of faith and learning that sanctified the ancestral land.

name: Monastery of Miracles (Surb Yerashkavor / Ardzge)
address: ≈3.5 km northwest of Adilcevaz, Bitlis Province, Turkey
description: This 8th-century monastery was revered as a place of healing and miracles. St. Vahan of Goght resided here, martyred around 737 for refusing to renounce Christianity. From the 14th–17th centuries it functioned as a scriptorium, with Archbishop Simeon restoring it in the 17th century. It was plundered and burned during the 1896 Hamidian massacres, and abandoned after the Armenian Genocide of 1915. Today only ruins remain, a silent witness to the spiritual strength and enduring mercy of Armenian faith.

name: Cathedral of the Holy Virgin (Surb Astvatsatsin), Adana
description: The grand Armenian Cathedral of the Holy Virgin in Adana was built in 1840 on the site of a 13th-century Cilician Armenian church. Dedicated to Surb Astvatsatsin, it became the spiritual and communal heart of Armenians in Adana. Expanded in the early 20th century under Archbishop Mushegh Seropian, it also served as the episcopal seat and housed a secondary school. After 1915 it was used as a military depot, later converted into the Tan Sineması cinema in the 1930s, and demolished in the 1970s to make way for the Central Bank’s regional headquarters. Today only the memory of this cathedral remains.

name: Church of the Holy Virgin (Surb Astvatsatsin), Kayseri
address: City center, Cumhuriyet District, Kayseri, Turkey
description: Built in the 19th century with funds from Karapet Zartaryan, this Armenian church once stood within Kayseri’s old city walls. After 1915 it was repurposed as an exhibition hall, police station, and gymnasium. Restoration began in 2017, and in 2020 it was reopened as a library holding 50,000 books. Today it stands as a memorial site for the spiritual life of Armenians in Kayseri.

name: Church of the Holy Sign (Surb Nshan), Kartal, Istanbul
description: Surb Nshan is an active Armenian Apostolic church in Kartal, founded in 1776 on the site of an earlier chapel. Rebuilt in 1857 by faithful Armenians led by Simon, Hagop, and Hadji Grigor Noradounian, it has remained a house of prayer for peace, the preservation of language, and faith. Coordinates verified by official geographic data.

name: Cathedral of the Holy Virgin (Surb Astvatsatsin), Kumkapı, Istanbul
address: Kumkapı Quarter, Fatih District, Istanbul, Turkey
description: The Cathedral of the Holy Virgin (Surb Astvatsatsin Atoranist Mother Cathedral) is the principal church of the Armenian Patriarchate of Constantinople. Rebuilt in 1828 after repeated fires, it has since remained the spiritual center of Istanbul Armenians. A school stood beside it, and in 1870 a stone bell tower was added. It continues to serve as a place of worship and spiritual guidance.

name: Church of the Holy King (Surb Tagavor), Kadıköy, Istanbul
description: Originally called Surb Astvatsatsin, this Armenian church dates back to at least 1722. Rebuilt in 1814 and restored after the 1840 earthquake, in 1858 it was renamed Surb Tagavor (“Holy King”). That year it also opened the Amazasbian and Muradian girls’ schools. Expanded in 1936, it underwent restorations in 2006 and 2011. Despite occasional vandalism, it remains a vital spiritual center for Istanbul’s Asian-side Armenian community.

name: Church of St. Peter (Surb Bedros), Gaziantep
description: Built in 1723, this Armenian church became a symbol of the faith of Armenians in Antep. In the 19th–20th centuries it was repurposed as a yarn warehouse and later as a cultural venue. Restored in 2008, it now serves as the Ömer Ersoy Cultural Center. Today it continues to stand as a testament to unshakable faith.

name: Monastery of St. Anania (Surb Anania), Por (Değirmenaltı)
address: Por (Değirmenaltı), 7 km northeast of Bitlis, Turkey
description: Founded in the 6th–7th centuries, rebuilt in the 15th century, this monastery featured a single nave with a domed apse and a zamatun (prayer gallery). Rows of khachkars dated to the 15th–16th centuries lined its southern wall. After the Genocide it was seized and used as a barn; only ruins remain today.

name: Church of St. Theodoros (Surb Teodoros), Bagaran
description: Built in 624–631 by Prince But Aravegyan and his wife Anna, this early domed cross-in-square church influenced Byzantine and European architecture. Its quadrifoil plan, dome on four supports, and large windows made it a masterpiece of early medieval Armenian design. Destroyed in the 1950s, only ruins remain.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator (Surb Grigor Lusavorich), Kuzguncuk, Istanbul
description: Originally a wooden church built in 1835, it was rebuilt in 1861 through the support of a pious benefactor. For generations it served as a parish center with an attached school. Restored in the 21st century, it continues to serve as a beacon of Armenian Christian faith.

name: Monastery of St. Thomas (Surb Tovmas), Van
address: ≈2 km northwest of Kanzak (Altınsaç), Gevaş District, Van Province, Turkey
description: Dating to the 10th–11th centuries, this monastery was built to house the relics of the Apostle Thomas, the “Enlightener of the East.” Once a flourishing scriptorium, it was fortified in the 17th century. Abandoned after 1915 and used as a sheepfold, today only ruins remain: the three-apse church, narthex, defensive walls, and cemetery.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator, Galata, Istanbul
description: Founded in 1360, repeatedly rebuilt after fires. Demolished in 1958 during urban renewal, it was rebuilt in 1962 and consecrated in 1966. Restored again in 2011, it remains a vibrant spiritual center for Armenians in Istanbul.

name: Church of St. Stepanos, Larnaca
description: Built in 1909 as a chapel in memory of victims of the Cilician massacres, it became a church in 1918. Restored in the mid-20th century and again in the 21st, with a khachkar added in 2009. Today it is a place of prayer and remembrance for the Armenian community.

name: Church of the Holy Virgin (Surb Astvatsatsin), Nicosia
description: Built in 1981 after the loss of the old church in the Turkish zone, with support from the Cypriot government and the World Council of Churches. Consecrated on 22 November 1981, it stands as a house of prayer, faith, and resilience for the Armenian community.

name: Church of St. George (Surb Kevork), Limassol
description: Founded in 1939, this church became the heart of the Limassol Armenian community. Services are held twice a month, and a school opened in 1951. It continues to serve as a place of prayer, education, and hope.
